componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jordan, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, and like to welcome everyone to the Pentair Q4 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Jim Lucas, you may begin your conference.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jordan. And welcome to Pentair's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. We're glad you can join us today.I'm Jim Lucas, Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategic Planning. With me today is Randy Hogan, our Chairman and Chief Exec
componenttext:
Thanks, Jordan. And welcome to Pentair's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. We're glad you can join us today.
I'm Jim Lucas, Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategic Planning. With me today is Randy Hogan, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Stauch, our Chief Financial Officer.
On today's call, we will provide details on our fourth quarter 2015 performance as well as our first quarter and full year 2016 outlook as outlined in this morning's release.
Before we begin, let me remind you that any statements made about the company's anticipated financial results are forward-looking statements subject to future risks and uncertainties, such as the risks outlined in Pentair's most recent 10-K and today's release.
Forward-looking statements included herein are made as of today, and the company undertakes no obligation to update publicly such statements to reflect subsequent events or circumstances. Actual results could differ materially from anticipated results.
Today's webcast is accompanied by a presentation, which can be found in the Investors section of Pentair's website. We will reference these slides throughout our prepared remarks. Any reference to non-GAAP financials are reconciled in the appendix of the presentation. We will be sure to reserve time for questions and answers after our prepared remarks. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now turn the call over to Randy.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with the executive summary on Page 4. There's no doubt that 2015 was a challenging year for Pentair and most other industrial companies, but we are encouraged that our fourth quarter results met our expe
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with the executive summary on Page 4. There's no doubt that 2015 was a challenging year for Pentair and most other industrial companies, but we are encouraged that our fourth quarter results met our expectations operationally. Overall, earnings came in higher than forecast due to a better ongoing tax rate, and our ability to forecast sales demonstrates that the quarter-to-quarter volatility in some of our served markets may finally be showing signs of stabilizing. 
While our businesses serving the Energy and Industrial markets will likely face continued challenges in 2016, the 2 bright spots in 2015, Food & Beverage and Residential & Commercial, appear to still have more upside. In addition, we've finally seen sign of stabilizations and green shoots of growth within our smaller vertical, Infrastructure. We understand way Valves & Controls focus for many of our investors and their efforts to rightsize the business in the face of this significant energy -- in the significant energy industry reset remains a big priority.
While we're now seeing sales and orders in Valves & Controls meet our forecast the second consecutive quarter, gross margins remain under pressure due to project pricing and mix. Our acquisition of ERICO completed at the end of the third quarter is delivering what we expected, and the integration is well underway. Cash flow, which has historically been a hallmark for Pentair, did come in slightly short of our forecast as we have foreshadowed in our outlook call last December. This is due exclusively to working capital timing and are fully committed to demonstrating our cash flow prowess in 2016, expecting greater than 100% adjusted net income conversion as we doubled down in working capital following the dramatic top line challenges faced in 2015, principally within Valves & Controls.
We're maintaining our 2016 full year adjusted EPS guidance of $4.05 per share to $4.25 per share. We made good progress on further reducing the tax rate as demonstrated in the fourth quarter. While this improved tax rate was just under a $0.10 compared to our prior forecast, we've lowered our Valves & Controls forecast by a similar mark, given the degree of margin compression the business has faced due to project pricing and uncertainty around the timing of the recovery in the short-cycle business, which slowed in 2015. Overall, we're pleased to have met our fourth quarter expectations, and our 2016 outlook remains intact. 
Now let's to Slide 5 for a discussion of our Q4 2015 results. Fourth quarter core sales declined 4%, which is a modest improvement from the 5% decline in the third quarter. Valves & Controls is slightly better in our sales forecast, and the rate of decline is stabilizing in the mid-teens. Water Quality Systems delivered strong 7% core growth. Core sales were flat and Flow & Filtration Solutions showed further signs of stabilization on the top line. Overall, FX remained a headwind in the quarter, and ERICO contributed positively and in line with our commitments.
Segment income declined 7%, and margins were down 90 basis points to 15.9%. As expected, Valves & Controls was a major contributor to margin contraction, while Water Quality Systems has a very strong margin quarter. Flow & Filtration Solutions had another quarter of margin expansion, which is why we believe this segment is well positioned for further gains in 2016. Due to the end-of-the-year tax adjustment, tax rate in the quarter was favorable, and our full year rate finished just north of 21%. We believe this is an ongoing rate and expect further improvement to the tax rate in 2016.
Free cash flow ended the year at $643 million, which is short of our $700 million forecast. As mentioned, free cash flow has been impacted by working capital timing due to the top line softness we've experienced so quickly, but we expect that free cash flow to return to greater than 100% of adjusted net income in 2016.
Now let's turn to Slide 6 to discuss Pentair's Q4 2015 performance elements. Our performance by vertical similar to the third quarter with solid gains in Residential & Commercial and Food & Beverage being offset by ongoing pressures in both Energy and Industrial. Encouragingly, Infrastructure was flat in the quarter and continue to show signs of stabilization and potential return to growth in 2016.
As you can see on the right-hand side of the page, we had another solid quarter of productivity and with price more than offset inflation. Our cost cut actions in Valves & Controls continued through 2015, and we still expect over $135 million in savings to read out in 2016. Negative mix impacted both Valves & Controls and Technical Solutions, but our other 2 segments, Flow & Filtration Solutions and Water Quality Systems, delivered improved margins.
Now let's turn to Slide 7 for a review Valves & Controls. The fourth quarter Valves & Controls core sales declined 15%, which is 1 point better than our forecast and an improvement from the 18% core decline experienced in the third quarter. FX remained a considerable headwind at 7%. Backlog was down 4%, which includes a negative FX translation. Core orders declined 15%, which is consistent with a double-digit rate of decline the business experienced throughout the year. Core sales declined in 3 of the 4 subverticals served by Valves & Controls as mining showed growth in the quarter on the results of 1 project shipping. We continue to see weakness in our short-cycle business as many of our customers have cut their operational budgets in addition to their capital budgets, including scaling back maintenance turnarounds. We do not expect this trend to revers in the third quarter remain optimistic that customers will begin spending more on maintenance as 2016 [ph] progresses. As we indicated last quarter, we've seen a trend of customers delaying shipment, but there are a few other cancellations in the current time. The right half of the page shows fourth quarter Valves & Controls segment income and margins. While we continue to drive productivity which offset inflation, it is not nearly enough to overcome the dramatic top line drop experienced during the quarter and the year. We've aggressively been rightsizing the cost structure, but it does take time for the benefits from those actions to read out. In addition, we've seen higher-than-normal margin compression due to pricing pressure within the project business. Mix has also been a headwind to margins as the higher-margin short-cycle businesses remain under pressure.
Now let's turn to Slide 8 for a look at the Valves & Controls backlog. As you can see on Slide 8 Valves & Controls backlog is broken down into 4 key subverticals, 3 of which fall into our Energy vertical, Oil & Gas, Power and Mining and one on our Industrial vertical, which is the Process business. Orders declined in all 4 of her subverticals with oil & gas the only business to not decline double digits. As 2015 progressed, we saw customers continue to curtail spending as they assess their long-term plans and adjusted to the reality of lower oil prices. Many expected Oil & Gas to feel the pressure but delays in project timing have extended to other areas like LNG and petrochem. As stated previously, it's not just been projects that had been delayed or cut. It's clearly customers have been delaying maintenance spending as well. It's still too early to call a bottom. We're encouraged that orders have met our forecast for the second consecutive quarter in the short-cycle business will return, but maintenance cannot be deferred for ever, and we're watching for some signs of improvement beginning the second quarter this year.
Now let's move to Slide 9 to discuss the Q4 performance of Flow & Filtration Solutions. Flow & Filtration Solutions had an 8% top line decline with core sales down 2% and foreign exchange translation of 6% headwind. The fourth quarter showed signs of stabilization segment. We continue to expect the business to return to growth in 2016. We did see all 4 served verticals contract in the quarter. Food & Beverage was down as growth in our beverage business was on not enough to offset the ongoing headwinds with agriculture. We would note that our sales decline in our agricultural-related businesses was not as bad as the overall industry. Residential & Commercial was down due to product line exits we made to better position this business longer-term. While Infrastructure overall is down, this was the result of the comparison last year when we had large filtration project shift. We're encouraged to see further improvement with our North America municipal pump business. Segment income was down modestly, but margins expanded 40 basis points to 11.3%. This marks the third consecutive quarter of year-over-year margin expansion and believe it a positive sign that the actions taken in 2015 positioned the segment for further gains in 2016 and beyond.
Now let's move to Slide 10 to look at Water Quality Systems. We believe that the slower top line growth seen in the third quarter was an anomaly, and the fourth quarter growth performance was validation that Water Quality Systems remains on a positive track. During the quarter, sales grew 4%, which consisted of 7% core sales growth offset by a 3% FX headwind. Both Residential & Commercial and Food & Beverage grew at high single-digit rates in the quarter. Our Aquatics business led the way once again, and pre-buy activity is a good foretoken that 2016 should be another good year for Aquatics. Our Water Purification business some favorable growth in Europe, which remained weak as distributors exhibited caution in their orders -- order patterns. Foodservice had another solid quarter and saw growth return in China after a pause in the third quarter. Segment income grew 30%, and margin expanded an impressive 450 basis points to 22.3%. This dramatic improvement was a combination of strong productivity execution and positive mix on top of an easier comparison against last year's fourth quarter results.
Water Quality Systems have proven to be a consistently high performer, and we remain committed to getting all of our businesses at the same level of performance.
Now let's move to Slide 11 for a look at how Technical Solutions performed in Q4. Technical Solutions reported 23% growth for the quarter, which consisted of flat core sales, a 6% headwind from FX and a 29% positive contribution from ERICO. Industrial sales were down 2% overall as we saw some further caution exercised by North American electrical distributor, offset partially by our Industrial heat tracing business. Energy was down 3% after growth in the past few quarters as a couple of larger heat tracing projects began to wind down. Infrastructure saw a modest 2% growth following tough year-over-year comparison the past 2 quarters. Residential & Commercial showed strong 7% core growth in the quarter, and ERICO, which generates a large portion of the sales from commercial, track with our expectations. Segment income grew 17%, while operating margins contracted 130 basis points to a still strong 22.6%. Principal factor contributing into margin performance in the fourth quarter was more project shipments and shipments within Industrial heat chasing, and the margin differential between them created the negative mix impact. ERICO met our income expectations, including synergies. While 2016 will see headwinds with the absence of 2 Energy projects and expected first half softness continuing in a short-cycle Industrial business, we remain focused on driving productivity and have taken further cost actions to deliver in this typically high-performance segment.
Let's now turn to Slide 12 for a look at our full year Pentair results. For the full year 2015, our core sales declined 4% as performance in Water Quality Systems and Technical Solutions was not enough to offset significant challenges faced by Valves & Controls served markets. Segment income declined 12%, and margins contracted 60 basis points to 15.5%. Our tax rate ended the year at just over 21%, which is better than the 23% we projected at the beginning of the year. We believe this improved tax rate is sustainable and would expect further improvement in reducing the tax rate in 2016. We're not pleased with our free cash flow performance of $643 million, which represented only 90% of adjusted net income, but we know this is fully to working capital timing and remain committed to correct it in 2016.
Overall, 2015 was a challenging year where we saw 2 of our segments deliver strong performance, 1 segment stabilize, and we're addressing the reality of the other segment.
Now let's turn to Slide 13 for the 2016 outlook assumptions. Before I turn the call over to John to provide additional insight on Valves & Controls and discuss our first quarter and 2016 outlook, I wanted to update you on what has changed since we issued our initial 2016 outlook in mid-December. As you can see on this slide, the majority for key assumptions remain unchanged. We continue to expect solid performance for our businesses serving Residential & Commercial and Food & Beverage. We've seen signs of stabilization within Infrastructure. Industrial is expected to continue to have a challenging first half of the year comparisons become less difficult in the second half, and we're encouraged that distributors may begin ordering once again in the back half of the year. Foreign exchange has been tracking to where we plan. We all know that this can change at any time. The one area that has worsen is Energy, particularly the further decline seen in the price of oil. We've seen several major energy companies announced capital expenditure plans and call for additional 20% plus cuts following the similar reductions in 2015. Further delays in the short-cycle business give us pause. Don't expect any signs of improvement in the first quarter, we watch the second quarter trends closely to see if customers stop deferring their maintenance spending. The other bright spot we have is the improvement in our tax rate. This added structural improvement provides an offset to further weakening in Energy and gives us increased confidence in maintaining our full year guidance.
With that, I'll turn the call over to John.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Randy. Please turn to Slide #14 titled V&C update. We thought it would be helpful to provide an update of our Valves & Controls business and the further deteriorating conditions that it's faced since issuing our initial 2006 guidance last Decem
componenttext:
Thank you, Randy. Please turn to Slide #14 titled V&C update. We thought it would be helpful to provide an update of our Valves & Controls business and the further deteriorating conditions that it's faced since issuing our initial 2006 guidance last December. We continue to see pressure on incoming orders and now expect orders to be down as much as 5% for the full year of 2016. The well-publicized decline in oil prices is just one of the factors that leads us to remain cautious about the timing of orders stabilization, but even more, we are watching the short-cycle business for signs that customers will begin to accelerate maintenance spending. As a result, we modestly lowered our full year revenue forecast for 2016. We continue to see pricing pressure on the project side of the business, and this shows up as margin compression. While we have aggressively implemented cost-out actions, we expect industry uncertainty to persist, we plan to remove additional cost in the business. When forecasting where we see sales and orders, coupled further anticipated margin compression, we're now forecasting return on sales in Valves & Controls to be 100 basis points lower than our original forecast at 10.5%.
Please turn to Slide #15 labeled noncash goodwill impairment. We performed step 1 of our goodwill impairment analysis as required by the accounting rules and concluded that the fair value of Valves & Controls is below its carrying value. The carrying value was determined when we completed the Flow Control merger in 2012 when oil was over $100 that year. Since 2012, the energy industry has reset significantly, and uncertainty remains around the timing of any recovery. We are finalizing the analysis, and we currently estimate that there'll be a noncash impairment charge in the range of $400 million to $600 million through reported at the time our 10-K was published. 
Please turn to Slide #16 labeled Balance Sheet and Cash Flow. Our balance sheet changed significantly with the closing of the ERICO acquisition. We added the -- we ended the year with $4.6 billion of net debt inclusive of cash on hand. While our balance sheet leveraged at 3.75x, higher than our targeted 2.5 leverage ratio, we expect to bring net leverage ratio at around 3.3 by the end of 2016. Our ROIC ended the quarter at 9.9% as our operating income came under pressure with the top line challenges experienced within our Valves & Controls segment. Although free cash flow ended the year roughly 90% of adjusted net income, this is due exclusively to working capital timing, and we expect the 100% conversion rate in 2016.
Please turn to Slide #17 labeled Q1 2016 Pentair outlook. For the first quarter, we expect core sales to be up a modest 1% and total sales to grow 7% inclusive of FX headwinds in the ERICO acquisition. On the core sales basis, we expect Valves & Controls to be down roughly 7%, which is the slower rate of decline to be expected in 2015. Flow & Filtration systems core sales are expected to be up 4% on easier year-over-year comparison and project shipment timing. Water Quality Systems core sales are anticipated to increase approximately 5% on continued strength in Aquatics. Finally, Technical Solutions core sales are expected to be up 4% and Industrial heat tracing helped to offset ongoing sluggishness and closures. We have not made any changes to our ERICO forecast or expectations around synergies. We are expecting segment income to decrease modestly and return on sales to contract 110 basis points.
Below the operating line, we expect an improved tax rate of around 20.5%. Net interest and other around $33 million and the share count around 183 million. Our first quarter adjusted EPS guidance is $0.70 to $0.72, which is roughly a 7% year-over-year decline.
We expect historically typical free cash flow usage in the first quarter but turning positive as the year progresses as we continue to focus on improving our working capital performance.
Please turn to Slide #18 labeled Full Year 2016 Pentair Outlook. We are maintaining our full year adjusted EPS outlook or $4.05 to $4.25, although the components have changed some from our initial outlook provided December. For the full year, we expect core sales decline of approximately 2%. Valves & Controls core sales are now anticipated to be down 8%, which is 3 points worse than our original forecast as I highlighted a few slides ago. We now expect Flow & Filtration core sales to be up modestly for the full year. Water Quality Systems core sales are anticipated to grow approximately 4%, and Technical Solutions core sales are expected to decline 4% for the full year. We expect segment income to be up 9%, and return on sales to expand 100 basis points to 16.5% with 3 of our 4 segments delivering full year margin expansion. We expect overall corporate cost to be approximately $90 million. Net interest and other to be around $135 million, our full year tax rate to be around 20.5% and the share count for the full year to be around 183 million. Adjusted EPS is expected to be up 5% at the midpoint of the range. Finally, we expect the strong year free cash flow expected to be approximately 100% of adjusted net income with our working capital opportunities providing potential upside. Jordan, can you please open the line for questions? Thank you.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Nigel Coe of Morgan Stanley.

componenttextpreview: I'm sure going to be you this Valves & Controls question, but I just want to switch to the other segments, and you raised outlook by around 1 point across the board, and you called out Infrastructure looks a bit better in '16 than perhaps back in December
componenttext: I'm sure going to be you this Valves & Controls question, but I just want to switch to the other segments, and you raised outlook by around 1 point across the board, and you called out Infrastructure looks a bit better in '16 than perhaps back in December. So maybe just comment on what you've seen in Infrastructure that makes you confident. Perhaps within TS, given the midstream CapEx outlook skin cuts, what gives you confidence that, that will be better back in December?

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Infrastructure is looking better, but also Aquatics is looking better in the Water Quality Systems Aquatics is the pool business, and it exited the year with a lot of -- with a really good tailwind. But in terms of Infrastructure, we've seen the ord
componenttext: Well, Infrastructure is looking better, but also Aquatics is looking better in the Water Quality Systems Aquatics is the pool business, and it exited the year with a lot of -- with a really good tailwind. But in terms of Infrastructure, we've seen the order rate pick up and our backlog pick up in both pumps and infiltration. So it's been a while building, and we expect that to actually lift growth for mostly flow and fluid solutions next year.

componenttext: Okay. And then -- Okay, great. On TS, Randy, what gives you more confidence there?

componenttext: It was the -- Nigel, what gives us more confidence in Technical Solutions, we're waiting to see where we ended the year with a backlog in Industrial solutions in its primary around the projects, and it ended stronger and therefore the backlog 2016 slightly higher.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Deane Dray with RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Deane Dray with RBC.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to touch on Valves & Controls first and maybe, you could update us on what the 2016 customer CapEx decline assumptions that you're making. We know since December oil has worsened, and you cited customers CapEx plans at 20%-plus down, but how are
componenttext: I wanted to touch on Valves & Controls first and maybe, you could update us on what the 2016 customer CapEx decline assumptions that you're making. We know since December oil has worsened, and you cited customers CapEx plans at 20%-plus down, but how are you thinking, broadly, if divided up between upstream, midstream, downstream?

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say, first and foremost, I don't think you see a lot of upstream activity, and a lot of these projects are in the process of being caught throughout the year, Dean. So we look at front log, which is things prior to coming into the cold funnel. S
componenttext: Well, I'd say, first and foremost, I don't think you see a lot of upstream activity, and a lot of these projects are in the process of being caught throughout the year, Dean. So we look at front log, which is things prior to coming into the cold funnel. So what are the opportunities you might be quoting in any given year, and that front log this year is significantly low as it relates to upstream activity. When we get into midstream, midstream still has a fair amount of the front log activity, and we are still a significant amount of midstream activity and in the downstream business we would expect that to be a productivity based investment, and we've seen delays in the quoting activity there. So we've got an order outlook next year as we suggested that's down further than what we anticipated, and then we expect the conversion ratio how many of those orders could be down further enhance that same taken down the Valves & Controls forecast even further.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I'm actually looking for is your broad market assumption about how much will your customer CapEx declines be in 2016. So we've seen estimates as high as -- down 35% in the upstream side. So I just want to know what assumptions are you making for your
componenttext: What I'm actually looking for is your broad market assumption about how much will your customer CapEx declines be in 2016. So we've seen estimates as high as -- down 35% in the upstream side. So I just want to know what assumptions are you making for your customers there CapEx plans for 2016?

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if I could, Dean, we haven't in the past sen a really good relationship between the CapEx numbers some of the big CapEx numbers and what it really happens our orders numbers. We've had -- as we've gotten better at forecasting our sales, what we've fo
componenttext: Yes, if I could, Dean, we haven't in the past sen a really good relationship between the CapEx numbers some of the big CapEx numbers and what it really happens our orders numbers. We've had -- as we've gotten better at forecasting our sales, what we've focused on is what John called that front log. We've seen a lot of projects that were being thought of that are no longer in that front log or things that we're chasing. So we're focusing on what's in our backlog and what we can shift and what is in the -- what real projects are in the front log and what our probability of getting when them and that's how we come to it.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair. And just in the pricing side, he called out pricing pressures on projects. We've seen that now for 1.5 years. Maybe give us some sense of how much pricing is down besides that and started to see pricing pressure on the short cycle. Look
componenttext: Okay. That's fair. And just in the pricing side, he called out pricing pressures on projects. We've seen that now for 1.5 years. Maybe give us some sense of how much pricing is down besides that and started to see pricing pressure on the short cycle. Look, everyone is seeing this. We're seeing that sector-wide, but give us a sense of what that's impacting on pricing on short cycle as well.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The short-cycle pricing, Dean, is called the Valves & Controls block because we list price as part number to part number, and therefore, the standard product is a light product. So you get a sense of where that price is. And right now, that's roughly arou
componenttext: The short-cycle pricing, Dean, is called the Valves & Controls block because we list price as part number to part number, and therefore, the standard product is a light product. So you get a sense of where that price is. And right now, that's roughly around 1% today. We're anticipating that to get a little bit tougher as we head into 2016. The majority for the call margin pressure is around the project site and the fact that the projects are coming through at a slightly lower margin, but we're also experiencing the mix differential between less standard product on the short-cycle and more of the projects coming out of the backlog. And that caught us by surprise in Q4, especially around December and we loaded in those expectations continuing to Q1 and ramping a little bit better to get the cost benefits reading out in Q2, Q3 and Q4 from our efforts.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And this is last question for me. On the free cash flow, you talked about this in December, so it's not a surprise that you came up short on the 2015 target. But just to clarify, was there any extension of payment terms for customers at year-end?
componenttext: Got it. And this is last question for me. On the free cash flow, you talked about this in December, so it's not a surprise that you came up short on the 2015 target. But just to clarify, was there any extension of payment terms for customers at year-end? We saw this in some of the other flow names that to help customers at year-end, was that a factor in this? And then real specific, when do you expect to recoup those receivables?

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first short answer is no to the first question. It's not something we've done or needed to do. And as you think about recovering this year, we felt like we had realized the impact of the working capital build right when I took over the interim role an
componenttext: The first short answer is no to the first question. It's not something we've done or needed to do. And as you think about recovering this year, we felt like we had realized the impact of the working capital build right when I took over the interim role and even after reducing those inventory levels and, therefore, getting after those receivable collections so we're very focused on getting the cash here in Q1 and Q2, and we feel like we're going to make good progress.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Steve Tusa with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Steve Tusa with JPMorgan.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- that chart that you guys gave, I think Slide #10 from your Investor Day, you talked about the Valves & Controls backlog and orders. First of all, the scheduled backlog of 9 90, is that still intact or has been some movement in that? And also, how d
componenttext: The -- that chart that you guys gave, I think Slide #10 from your Investor Day, you talked about the Valves & Controls backlog and orders. First of all, the scheduled backlog of 9 90, is that still intact or has been some movement in that? And also, how do I reconcile the orders down 8 in that slide and the orders of flat to down 5? Is that just short-cycle orders you're talking about?

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So real quickly, we're down about $40 million to $50 million on the starting backlog position, Steve, and that would represent movements out of 2016 into '17, and that's what we know of today. The orders on slide the same number, I apologize, 1 this quart
componenttext: So real quickly, we're down about $40 million to $50 million on the starting backlog position, Steve, and that would represent movements out of 2016 into '17, and that's what we know of today. The orders on slide the same number, I apologize, 1 this quarter and one is inclusive of FX, so roughly the same. What we're having a little bit of change to our forecast on is we usually convert about half of those orders within a year, but we're expecting the orders to be a little bit more backend-loaded and, therefore, we won't be getting as many of the orders shipped in 2016 as we originally anticipated.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the start to the year in Valves & Controls, the 6.5% margin, I don't recall it being that seasonal historically. Is there something, I guess, just a function of the timing of the cost saves ramping throughout the course of the year? Anythin
componenttext: Okay. And then the start to the year in Valves & Controls, the 6.5% margin, I don't recall it being that seasonal historically. Is there something, I guess, just a function of the timing of the cost saves ramping throughout the course of the year? Anything unusual here in the first quarter to have that -- and that's kind of unusually low margin rate.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's 3 things, Steve. One is we have unusually low shipment number of 385, and then we haven't been below 400 in this business in sometime, and that reflects the shippable backlog, but it also reflects the #2 issue, which is we're expecting the
componenttext: I think there's 3 things, Steve. One is we have unusually low shipment number of 385, and then we haven't been below 400 in this business in sometime, and that reflects the shippable backlog, but it also reflects the #2 issue, which is we're expecting the standard product to be slow again in Q1 as we wait for customers to get their expense budgets aligned and decide where they're going to spend their expense and maintenance dollars, so we have a low mix ratio related to that and also lower expectation. And then the third element is exactly what you said. We've recognized about $11 million to $12 million on a quarterly basis on the cost takeout in the 150, and that ramps throughout the year, and the first quarter reflects what we have to do with inventory accounting and putting that into the inventory and then shipping the old inventory first before we can recognize the benefits. So those are the 3 unusual aspects to Q1.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, one last quick one. You mentioned weakness in LNG. I know it's kind of a slow-moving train here over the course of the next couple of years and should roll down dramatically toward the end of the decade. I guess are you surprised at how early you a
componenttext: Sorry, one last quick one. You mentioned weakness in LNG. I know it's kind of a slow-moving train here over the course of the next couple of years and should roll down dramatically toward the end of the decade. I guess are you surprised at how early you are seeing some weakness there? Is that just -- are they canceling some projects? Is there destocking going on there? I know some of the compression orders and others have been very, very weak on that front. I'm just trying to kind of understand the timing because -- yes. Just on the timing of the LNG stuff what you're seeing there.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our view is, ultimately, LNG is going to play a bigger role in the energy mix worldwide, and the U.S. will be and should be a net exporter. There were a lot of projects in and planning. They were pretty much put on the shelf, and some of the other ones th
componenttext: Our view is, ultimately, LNG is going to play a bigger role in the energy mix worldwide, and the U.S. will be and should be a net exporter. There were a lot of projects in and planning. They were pretty much put on the shelf, and some of the other ones that actually were in design have been slowed down. So that was the reference that we're talking about because we're looking at things we were expecting to be happening the near term versus they may still happen but they may be 2 or 3 years out now, '16, '17.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think what were were hitting on Analyst Day at where people are bullish about that activity because of lower feedstock, you got to look at global demand, and the global demand just isn't there at the rate that would support all of those projects com
componenttext: And I think what were were hitting on Analyst Day at where people are bullish about that activity because of lower feedstock, you got to look at global demand, and the global demand just isn't there at the rate that would support all of those projects coming through. So I guess to answer your question, we're surprise this whole Energy aspect, no, we're not surprised.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh no, I get that. I think it's going to be a debacle at some point in the next couple of years but the timing is kind of hard to nail down just because of the -- how big these projects are and the multiyear nature of them, so I'm just more of a timing qu
componenttext: Oh no, I get that. I think it's going to be a debacle at some point in the next couple of years but the timing is kind of hard to nail down just because of the -- how big these projects are and the multiyear nature of them, so I'm just more of a timing question than anything else.

componenttext: Well, this year, we're expecting mid-single-digits in the U.S. And actually, we've seen some life in Europe as well. We actually saw some growth in the fourth quarter and the water quality a little bit in the Aquatics business and the Water Purification part of water quality both those both being Water Quality Systems. So the stronger Europe than last year and continuing strength in the U.S. multifamily and then continuing as home prices increase, the flow business is back and there's the innovation switch to Energy saving products and more sustainable products are still at that conversion is still happen and readily than that. So all of the things that's been working for us in Aquatics is still working.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe going to Steve's question earlier around the V&C margin ramp post 1Q. It looks like you guys stepped up your cost up to 150. Should we be thinking about the benefits coming through in a linear fashion starting in 2Q or is there a ramp as the year
componenttext: So maybe going to Steve's question earlier around the V&C margin ramp post 1Q. It looks like you guys stepped up your cost up to 150. Should we be thinking about the benefits coming through in a linear fashion starting in 2Q or is there a ramp as the year progresses?

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a ramp as we progress. I mean we'd be at full Apple rate right around Q3, and it really is more about the manufacturing cost-out having to work its way through the inventory side. The benefits on the selling and marketing some of the benefits in t
componenttext: There's a ramp as we progress. I mean we'd be at full Apple rate right around Q3, and it really is more about the manufacturing cost-out having to work its way through the inventory side. The benefits on the selling and marketing some of the benefits in the G&A are linear, and we've got most of those behind us, and so those are going to be experienced in Q1, 2, 3, 4 pretty evenly, and the manufacturing side has to work its way through the inventory, and have to move the old inventory out first. And we don't have the quickest inventory turns in this business, so that's why it takes till the end of Q2 to really get on a full run rate for Q3 and Q4.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We also believe the mix between short cycle and projects -- short-cycle and aftermarket projects are going to improve.
componenttext: We also believe the mix between short cycle and projects -- short-cycle and aftermarket projects are going to improve.

Or are we getting closer to the maximum amount that you can actually take out before you start to impact the new service levels?

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I never like to say never, but I think we'd have to think differently about. I mean the team there has done a heroic job of adjusting the cost structure to one of the most precipitous drops in sales that I've ever seen, and they're executing well. W
componenttext: Well, I never like to say never, but I think we'd have to think differently about. I mean the team there has done a heroic job of adjusting the cost structure to one of the most precipitous drops in sales that I've ever seen, and they're executing well. We'd have to think about it more creatively before we need to do anything else in terms of costs. I mean just conduction conjecture at this point. I think as the forecast that John showed you is -- and I understand first quarter is lower than was expected and it really is that mix of the cost readout and the overall volume levels John said. The shipment volume below $400 million in our records.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we didn't have it in our numbers either. Maybe one broader question in just Valves & Controls as you think about the portfolio longer-term currently when you brought this asset back in 2012, it turned out to be a lot more cyclical than you guys initi
componenttext: Yes, we didn't have it in our numbers either. Maybe one broader question in just Valves & Controls as you think about the portfolio longer-term currently when you brought this asset back in 2012, it turned out to be a lot more cyclical than you guys initially anticipated. How do you guys think about the long-term opportunity for Valves & Controls within this portfolio? And is there an opportunity to maybe think about whether Valves & Controls should actually even be part of the product portfolio?

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It may be hard for people to believe, but we still believe this Valves & Controls business is high-quality business with good people and a lot of the product lines are real crown jewels. Not all of them but a lot of them are. Right now, it's certainly is
componenttext: It may be hard for people to believe, but we still believe this Valves & Controls business is high-quality business with good people and a lot of the product lines are real crown jewels. Not all of them but a lot of them are. Right now, it's certainly is -- it certainly is to the rest of the business, which is rising, and so we want to correct that, and we wanted this diversity, this exposure to energy. I would say this is much more than a cyclical term. This is -- there hasn't been anything as the best since the '80s, and so I think it's too early to conjecture.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, either way, what Randy asked me to do with how do we think about it is more predictable consistent earnings stream, meaning a lot less project dependent a lot more after markets and in making sure we understand where customers value what we
componenttext: Yes, I think, either way, what Randy asked me to do with how do we think about it is more predictable consistent earnings stream, meaning a lot less project dependent a lot more after markets and in making sure we understand where customers value what we sell and that they don't value with B cell and then thinking about the fact that when you lost this amount of revenue, which is important area is your income and the margin dollars as you think forward. So either way, we're going to make this a really good business, and I think think we had the opportunity to take what readies direction and have a value in the future.

componenttext: In terms of this watching the short cycle in Valves & Controls and the maintenance spending, there's been a view from you guys and others that you can't defer maintenance forever, and it should come back but we're probably a few quarters past where a lot of people thought it would start to come back already so more visibility into could this really be continue to get people finding other ways to actually operate without doing the typical maintenance into that...?

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have real examples of people servicing the valves instead of what they would've replaced before, insourcing service to keep their people busy if they have them versus where they would've usually contracted it. That sorts itself out and lapse itself. We
componenttext: We have real examples of people servicing the valves instead of what they would've replaced before, insourcing service to keep their people busy if they have them versus where they would've usually contracted it. That sorts itself out and lapse itself. We saw it was worse in the second half than the first half, and it's worse in the fourth quarter than the average in the second half, and that can continue. These are a lot -- these are mission-critical products that are part of processes that are precision and can be by law, they have to be serviced. And so they can't do it forever. I mean right now, as you think have been great us for us to whether a fight every to better. Ultimately they have to maintain them. So that's the other thing. One, a shift from lower cost in servicing. And then there's the fact that they can run them a little bit harder when the track spreads are high.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just look at the mix issue that you're talking about, Randy, I understand that short-cycle orders or probably short-cycle revenues drop up for project revenues do, but I thought that eventually project revenues will decline more than the short-
componenttext: If I could just look at the mix issue that you're talking about, Randy, I understand that short-cycle orders or probably short-cycle revenues drop up for project revenues do, but I thought that eventually project revenues will decline more than the short-cycle revenues, and you will actually flip that mix from being a headwind to a tailwind. Can you talk about how that progresses through the year or into next year and what kind of impact you'd expect to have an margins as we progress through that mix shift?

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we look at business by business. In Valves & Controls, actually, the short-cycle held up much better than projects. So it really was in the fourth quarter way where the decline was about the same. So we would expect that -- we don't think it
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we look at business by business. In Valves & Controls, actually, the short-cycle held up much better than projects. So it really was in the fourth quarter way where the decline was about the same. So we would expect that -- we don't think it gets better in the first quarter, that's why we're saying that we're watching to see improvements and we're certainly taking actions to help improve that in Valves & Controls. In the case of Technical Solutions where we have the Industrial heat trace projects where a lot of them are not oil & gas-related, they're other industries, and the backlog is good there. There's a hopping business being down and versus those project. That gets better in the second half because just by comparison, because was down in second half and we don't think it's -- as we get to lapping that we don't think we'll see further down there should be a mix improvement in Technical Solutions in the second half.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're right long term as you work the backlog off and you work the large projects off, those 2 have a lower margin and mix overall, over time, should be a mix benefit. And that being said, as Randy was just saying, we ship about $900 million of s
componenttext: I think you're right long term as you work the backlog off and you work the large projects off, those 2 have a lower margin and mix overall, over time, should be a mix benefit. And that being said, as Randy was just saying, we ship about $900 million of short cycle, so it would take a lot of incremental short-cycle sales to pick up the project sales to decline itself and factories as well and work our way through this so. I think it's short-term issue on the mix challenges, and I think the business will sort its way out, and I think there's still productivity opportunities, and I think it's in the '17 before we see that turning favorable.

componenttext: Just from a high-level perspective, just I want to make sure I'm understanding this correctly. headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

Good morning. My name is Jordan, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Pentair Q4 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
Jim Lucas, you may begin your conference.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jordan. And welcome to Pentair's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. We're glad you can join us today.I'm Jim Lucas, Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategic Planning. With me today is Randy Hogan, our Chairman and Chief Exec
componenttext:
Thanks, Jordan. And welcome to Pentair's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. We're glad you can join us today.
I'm Jim Lucas, Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategic Planning. With me today is Randy Hogan, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Stauch, our Chief Financial Officer.
On today's call, we will provide details on our fourth quarter 2015 performance as well as our first quarter and full year 2016 outlook as outlined in this morning's release.
Before we begin, let me remind you that any statements made about the company's anticipated financial results are forward-looking statements subject to future risks and uncertainties, such as the risks outlined in Pentair's most recent 10-K and today's release.
Forward-looking statements included herein are made as of today, and the company undertakes no obligation to update publicly such statements to reflect subsequent events or circumstances. Actual results could differ materially from anticipated results.
Today's webcast is accompanied by a presentation, which can be found in the Investors section of Pentair's website. We will reference these slides throughout our prepared remarks. Any references to non-GAAP financials are reconciled in the appendix of the presentation. We will be sure to reserve time for questions and answers after our prepared remarks. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now turn the call over to Randy.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with the executive summary on Page 4. There's no doubt that 2015 was a challenging year for Pentair and most other industrial companies, but we are encouraged that our fourth quarter results met our expe
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with the executive summary on Page 4. There's no doubt that 2015 was a challenging year for Pentair and most other industrial companies, but we are encouraged that our fourth quarter results met our expectations operationally. Overall, earnings came in higher than forecast due to a better ongoing tax rate, and our ability to forecast sales demonstrates that the quarter-to-quarter volatility in some of our served markets may finally be showing signs of stabilizing. 
While our businesses serving the Energy and Industrial markets will likely face continued challenges in 2016, the 2 bright spots in 2015, Food & Beverage and Residential & Commercial, appear to still have more upside. In addition, we've finally seen signs of stabilizations and some green shoots of growth within our smallest vertical, Infrastructure. We understand why Valves & Controls have been a focus of many of our investors as our efforts to rightsize the business in the face of this significant energy -- in the significant energy industry reset remains a big priority.
While we're now seeing sales and orders in Valves & Controls meet our forecast for the second consecutive quarter, gross margins remain under pressure due to project pricing and mix. Our acquisition of ERICO completed at the end of the third quarter is delivering what we expected, and the integration is well underway. Cash flow, which has historically been a hallmark for Pentair, did come in slightly short of our forecast as we had foreshadowed in our outlook call last December. This is due exclusively to working capital timing and we're fully committed to demonstrating our cash flow prowess in 2016, expecting greater than 100% adjusted net income conversion as we doubled down on working capital following the dramatic top line challenges faced in 2015, principally within Valves & Controls.
We're maintaining our 2016 full year adjusted EPS guidance of $4.05 per share to $4.25 per share. We made good progress on further reducing the tax rate as demonstrated in the fourth quarter. While this improved tax rate will add just under $0.10 compared to our prior forecast, we've lowered our Valves & Controls forecast by a similar amount, given the degree of margin compression the business has faced due to project pricing and uncertainty around the timing of the recovery in the short-cycle business, which slowed in 2015. Overall, we're pleased to have met our fourth quarter expectations, and our 2016 outlook remains intact. 
Now let's turn to Slide 5 for a discussion of our Q4 2015 results. Fourth quarter core sales declined 4%, which is a modest improvement from the 5% decline in the third quarter. Valves & Controls was slightly better than our sales forecast, and the rate of decline is stabilizing in the mid-teens. Water Quality Systems delivered strong 7% core growth. Technical Solutions core sales were flat and Flow & Filtration Solutions showed further signs of stabilization on the top line. Overall, FX remained a headwind in the quarter, and ERICO contributed positively and in line with our commitments.
Segment income declined 7%, and margins were down 90 basis points to 15.9%. As expected, Valves & Controls was the major contributor to the margin contraction, while Water Quality Systems had a very strong margin quarter. Flow & Filtration Solutions had another quarter of margin expansion, which is why we believe this segment is well positioned for further gains in 2016. Due to end-of-the-year tax adjustment, the tax rate in the quarter was favorable, and our full year rate finished just north of 21%. We believe this is an ongoing rate and expect further improvements to the tax rate in 2016.
Free cash flow ended the year at $643 million, which was short of our $700 million forecast. As mentioned, free cash flow has been impacted by working capital timing due to the top line softness we've experienced so quickly, but we expect that free cash flow to return to greater than 100% of adjusted net income in 2016.
Now let's turn to Slide 6 to discuss Pentair's Q4 2015 performance elements. Our performance by vertical was similar to the third quarter, with solid gains in Residential & Commercial and Food & Beverage being offset by ongoing pressures in both Energy and Industrial. Encouragingly, Infrastructure was flat in the quarter and continue to show signs of stabilization and potential return to growth in 2016.
As you can see on the right-hand side of the page, we had another solid quarter of productivity and with price, they more than offset inflation. Our cost cut actions in Valves & Controls continued through 2015, and we still expect over $135 million in savings to read out in 2016. Negative mix impacted both Valves & Controls and Technical Solutions, but our other 2 segments, Flow & Filtration Solutions and Water Quality Systems, delivered improved margins.
Now let's turn to Slide 7 for a review of Valves & Controls. For the fourth quarter Valves & Controls core sales declined 15%, which is a point better than our forecast and an improvement from the 18% core decline experienced in the third quarter. FX remained a considerable headwind at 7%. Backlog was down 4%, which includes the negative FX translation. Core orders declined 15%, which is consistent with the double-digit rate of decline the business experienced throughout the year. Core sales declined in 3 of the 4 subverticals served by Valves & Controls as mining showed growth in the quarter on the results of one project shipping. 
We continue to see weakness in our short-cycle business as many of our customers have cut their operational budgets in addition to their capital budgets, including scaling back maintenance turnarounds. We do not expect this trend to reverse in the first quarter. We'll remain optimistic that customers will begin spending more on maintenance as 2006 (sic) progresses. 
As we indicated last quarter, we've seen a trend of customers delaying shipment, but there are a few order cancellations at the current time. The right half of the page shows fourth quarter Valves & Controls segment income and margins. While we continued to drive productivity, which offset inflation, it is not nearly enough to overcome the dramatic top line drop experienced during the quarter and the year. We've aggressively been rightsizing the cost structure, but it does take time for the benefits from those actions to read out. In addition, we've seen higher-than-normal margin compression due to pricing pressure within the project business. Mix has also been a headwind to margins as the higher-margin and short-cycle businesses has remained under pressure.
Now let's turn to Slide 8 for a look at the Valves & Controls backlog. As you can see on Slide 8 Valves & Controls backlog is broken down into 4 key subverticals, 3 of which fall into our Energy vertical, Oil & Gas, Power and Mining, and one in our Industrial vertical, which is the Process business. 
Orders declined in all 4 of our subverticals, with Oil & Gas the only business to not decline double digits. As 2015 progressed, we saw customers continue to curtail spending as they assess their long-term plans and adjusted to the reality of lower oil prices. Many expected Oil & Gas to feel the pressure, but delays in project timing have extended to other areas like LNG and petrochem. As stated previously, it has not just been projects that had been delayed or cut. It's clear the customers have been delaying maintenance spending as well. It's still too early to call a bottom. We're encouraged that orders have met our forecast for the second consecutive quarter. It's uncertain when the short-cycle business will return, but maintenance cannot be deferred forever, and we're watching for some signs of improvement beginning the second quarter this year.
Now let's move to Slide 9 to discuss the Q4 performance of Flow & Filtration Solutions. Flow & Filtration Solutions had an 8% top line decline, with core sales down 2% and foreign exchange translation of 6% headwind. The fourth quarter showed signs of stabilization with the segment. We continue to expect the business to return to growth in 2016. 
We did see all 4 served verticals contract in the quarter. Food & Beverage was down as growth in our beverage business was not enough to offset the ongoing headwinds within agriculture. We would note that our sales decline in our agriculture-related businesses was not as bad as the overall industry. Residential & Commercial was down due to product line exits we made to better position this business longer-term. While Infrastructure overall was down, this was the result of a tough comparison last year when we had a large filtration project shift. 
We're encouraged to see further improvement with our North America municipal pump business. Segment income was down modestly, but margins expanded 40 basis points to 11.3%. This marks the third consecutive quarter of year-over-year margin expansion and believe it a positive sign that the actions taken in 2015 positioned the segment for further gains in 2016 and beyond.
Now let's move to Slide 10 to look at Water Quality Systems. We believe that the slower top line growth seen in the third quarter was an anomaly, and the fourth quarter growth performance was validation that Water Quality Systems remains on a positive track. During the quarter, sales grew 4%, which consisted of 7% core sales growth offset by a 3% FX headwind. Both Residential & Commercial and Food & Beverage grew at high single-digit rates in the quarter. 
Our Aquatics business led the way once again, and pre-buy activity is a good foretoken that 2016 should be another good year for Aquatics. Our Water Purification business saw favorable growth in Europe, but China remained weak as distributors exhibited caution in their orders -- order patterns. Foodservice had another solid quarter and saw growth return in China after a pause in the third quarter. Segment income grew 30%, and margin expanded an impressive 450 basis points to 22.3%. This dramatic improvement was the combination of strong productivity execution and positive mix on top of an easier comparison against last year's fourth quarter results.
Water Quality Systems has proven to be a consistently high performer, and we remain committed to getting all of our businesses to the same level of performance.
Now let's move to Slide 11 for a look at how Technical Solutions performed in Q4. Technical Solutions reported 23% growth for the quarter, which consisted of flat core sales, a 6% headwind from FX and a 29% positive contribution from ERICO. Industrial sales were down 2% overall as we saw further caution exercised by North American electrical distributors, offset partially by our Industrial heat tracing business. 
Energy was down 3% after growth in the past few quarters as a couple of larger heat tracing projects began to wind down. Infrastructure saw a modest 2% growth following tough year-over-year comparison the past 2 quarters. Residential & Commercial showed strong 7% core growth in the quarter, and ERICO, which generates a large portion of the sales from commercial, track with our expectations. 
Segment income grew 17%, while operating margins contracted 130 basis points to a still strong 22.6%. Principal factor contributing to margin performance in the fourth quarter was more project shipments than product shipments within Industrial heat tracing, and the margin differential between them created a negative mix impact. ERICO met our income expectations, including synergies. While 2016 will see headwinds with the absence of 2 Energy projects and expected first half softness continuing in a short-cycle Industrial business, we remain focused on driving productivity and have taken further cost actions to deliver in this typically high-performance segment.
Let's now turn to Slide 12 for a look at our full year Pentair results. For the full year 2015, our core sales declined 4% as performance in Water Quality Systems and Technical Solutions was not enough to offset significant challenges faced by Valves & Controls served markets. Segment income declined 12%, and margins contracted 60 basis points to 15.5%. Our tax rate ended the year at just over 21%, which was better than the 23% we projected at the beginning of the year. We believe this improved tax rate is sustainable and would expect further improvement in reducing the tax rate in 2016. 
We're not pleased with our free cash flow performance of $643 million, which represented only 90% of adjusted net income, but we know this is due fully to working capital timing and remain committed to correct it in 2016.
Overall, 2015 was a challenging year where we saw 2 of our segments deliver strong performance, one segment stabilize, and we're addressing the reality of the other segment.
Now let's turn to Slide 13 for the 2016 outlook assumptions. Before I turn the call over to John to provide additional insight on Valves & Controls and to discuss our first quarter and 2016 outlook, I wanted to update you on what has changed since we issued our initial 2016 outlook in mid-December. As you can see on this slide, the majority of our key assumptions remain unchanged. We continue to expect solid performance for our businesses serving Residential & Commercial and Food & Beverage. We've seen signs of stabilization within Infrastructure. Industrial is expected to continue to have a challenging first half of the year, but comparisons become less difficult in the second half, and we're encouraged that distributors may begin ordering once again in the back half of the year. Foreign exchange has been tracking to where we plan. We all know that this can change at any time. 
The one area that has worsened is Energy, particularly the further decline seen in the price of oil. We've seen several major energy companies announce capital expenditure plans and call for additional 20% plus cuts following similar reductions in 2015. Further the delays in the short-cycle business give us pause. Don't expect any signs of improvement in the first quarter, and we'll watch the second quarter trends closely to see if customers stop deferring their maintenance spending. The other bright spot we have is the improvement in our tax rate. This added structural improvement provides an offset to the further weakening in Energy and gives us increased confidence in maintaining our full year guidance.
With that, I'll turn the call over to John.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Randy. Please turn to Slide #14 titled V&C Update. We thought it would be helpful to provide an update on our Valves & Controls business and the further deteriorating conditions that it's faced since issuing our initial 2006 guidance last Decem
componenttext:
Thank you, Randy. Please turn to Slide #14 titled V&C Update. We thought it would be helpful to provide an update on our Valves & Controls business and the further deteriorating conditions that it's faced since issuing our initial 2006 guidance last December. We continue to see pressure on incoming orders and now expect orders to be down as much as 5% for the full year of 2016. The well-publicized decline in oil prices is just one of the factors that leads us to remain cautious about the timing of order stabilization, but even more, we are watching the short-cycle business for signs that customers will begin to accelerate maintenance spending. As a result, we have modestly lowered our full year revenue forecast for 2016. 
We continue to see pricing pressure on the project side of the business, and this shows up as margin compression. While we have aggressively implemented cost-out actions, we expect industry uncertainty to persist, and we plan to remove additional cost from the business. When forecasting where we see sales and orders, coupled with further anticipated margin compression, we now are forecasting return on sales in Valves & Controls to be 100 basis points lower than our original forecast at 10.5%.
Please turn to Slide #15 labeled Noncash Goodwill Impairment. We performed Step 1 of our goodwill impairment analysis as required by the accounting rules and concluded that the fair value of Valves & Controls is below its carrying value. The carrying value was determined when we completed the Flow Control merger in 2012 when oil was over $100 that year. Since 2012, the energy industry has reset significantly, and uncertainty remains around the timing of any recovery. We are finalizing the analysis, but we currently estimate that there will be a noncash impairment charge in the range of $400 million to $600 million to be recorded at the time that our 10-K is published.
Please turn to Slide #16 labeled Balance Sheet and Cash Flow. Our balance sheet changed significantly with the closing of the ERICO acquisition. We added the -- ended the year with $4.6 billion of net debt inclusive of cash on hand. While our balance sheet leveraged at 3.75x, higher than our targeted 2.5 leverage ratio, we expect to bring net leverage ratio to around 3.3 by the end of 2016. 
Our ROIC ended the quarter at 9.9% as our operating income came under pressure with the top line challenges experienced within our Valves & Controls segment. Although free cash flow ended the year at roughly 90% of adjusted net income, this was due exclusively to working capital timing, and we expect a 100% conversion rate in 2016.
Please turn to Slide #17 labeled Q1 2016 Pentair Outlook. For the first quarter, we expect core sales to be up a modest 1% and total sales to grow 7% inclusive of FX headwinds in the ERICO acquisition. On a core sales basis, we expect Valves & Controls to be down roughly 7%, which is a slower rate of decline than we experienced throughout 2015. 
Flow & Filtration systems core sales are expected to be up 4% on an easier year-over-year comparison than project shipment timing. Water Quality Systems core sales are anticipated to increase approximately 5% on continued strength in Aquatics. 
Finally, Technical Solutions core sales are expected to be up 4% as Industrial heat tracing and electronics helped to offset ongoing sluggishness and closures. We have not made any changes to our ERICO forecast or expectations around synergies. We are expecting segment income to decrease modestly and return on sales to contract 110 basis points.
Below the operating line, we expect an improved tax rate of around 20.5%. Net interest and other around $33 million and the share count around 183 million. Our first quarter adjusted EPS guidance is $0.70 to $0.72, which is roughly a 7% year-over-year decline.
We expect historically typical free cash flow usage in the first quarter, but turning positive as the year progresses as we continue to focus on improving our working capital performance.
Please turn to Slide #18 labeled Full Year 2016 Pentair Outlook. We are maintaining our full year adjusted EPS outlook or $4.05 to $4.25, although the components have changed some from our initial outlook provided in December. For the full year, we expect core sales to decline approximately 2%. Valves & Controls core sales are now anticipated to be down 8%, which is 3 points worse than our original forecast as I highlighted a few slides ago. We now expect Flow & Filtration core sales to be up modestly for the full year. Water Quality Systems core sales are anticipated to grow approximately 4%, and Technical Solutions core sales are expected to decline 4% for the full year. 
We expect segment income to be up 9%, and return on sales to expand 100 basis points to 16.5% with 3 of our 4 segments delivering full year margin expansion. We expect overall corporate cost to be approximately $90 million. Net interest and other to be around $135 million, our full year tax rate to be around 20.5% and the share count for the full year to be around 183 million. Adjusted EPS is expected to be up 5% at the midpoint of the range. 
Finally, we expect the strong year of free cash flow expect it to be approximately 100% of adjusted net income with our working capital opportunities providing potential upside. 
Jordan, can you please open the line for questions? Thank you.

headline: Pentair plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttextpreview: Well, Infrastructure is looking better, but also Aquatics is looking better. I mean, the Water Quality Systems Aquatics is the pool business, and it exited the year with a lot of -- with a really good tailwind. But in terms of Infrastructure, we've seen t
componenttext: Well, Infrastructure is looking better, but also Aquatics is looking better. I mean, the Water Quality Systems Aquatics is the pool business, and it exited the year with a lot of -- with a really good tailwind. But in terms of Infrastructure, we've seen the order rate pick up and our backlog pick up in both pumps and infiltration. So it's been a while building, and we expect that to actually lift growth for mostly flow and fluid solutions next year.
