headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. This is Steve, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Pentair First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Jim Lucas, Vice
componenttext: Good morning. This is Steve, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Pentair First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Jim Lucas, Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategic Planning. Please go ahead.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and welcome to Pentair's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. We are glad you can join us. I'm Jim Lucas, Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategic Planning, and with me today is Randy Hogan, our Chairman and Chief Executiv
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and welcome to Pentair's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. We are glad you can join us. I'm Jim Lucas, Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategic Planning, and with me today is Randy Hogan, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Stauch, our Chief Financial Officer. On today's call, we will provide details on our first quarter 2016 performance as well as our second quarter and full year 2016 outlook as outlined in this morning's release. 
Before we begin, let me remind you that any statements made about the company's anticipated financial results are forward-looking statements subject to future risks and uncertainties, such as the risks outlined in Pentair's most recent 10-K and today's release. Forward-looking statements included herein are made as of today, and the company undertakes no obligation to update publicly such statements to reflect subsequent events or circumstances. Actual results could differ materially from anticipated results. 
Today's webcast is accompanied by a presentation, which can be found in the Investors section of Pentair's website. We will reference these slides throughout our prepared remarks. Any references to non-GAAP financials are reconciled in the appendix of the presentation. We will be sure to reserve time for questions and answers after our prepared remarks. [Operator Instructions] 
And I will now turn the call over to Randy.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. We are pleased with our first quarter results, beating the expectations set at the beginning of the year. The top line was consistent with expectations, and we saw strong execution on all businesses led by 3 segmen
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. We are pleased with our first quarter results, beating the expectations set at the beginning of the year. The top line was consistent with expectations, and we saw strong execution on all businesses led by 3 segments delivering over 100 basis points of margin expansion each. 
We recently announced a new leader for our Valves & Controls segment. We're all glad to have Dennis Cassidy [indiscernible] join us, most recently from Alex Partners. I appreciate John Stauch leaning in and leading Valves & Controls the past few quarters. The Valves & Controls business delivered first quarter results in line with our guidance. 
The Integration of ERICO is meeting our expectations, and we believe we are on track to meet or exceed the $10 million in synergies we targeted. 
Free cash flow, while seasonally usage during the quarter, was much better than the comparable period last year. Given the stronger start to free cash flow this year, we feel good about our ability to deliver approximately $750 million in free cash this year. 
We are maintaining our 2016 full year adjusted EPS outlook of $4.05 to $4.25 per share. Execution for cash and earnings remain our key focus and the first quarter gives us a good start to the year. 
Now let's turn to Slide 5 for a discussion of our Q1 2016 results in more detail. First quarter core sales grew 1%, which was an improvement from the declines we saw the past couple quarters. 3 of our 4 segments met or beat their top line commitments, with Flow & Filtration Solutions being negatively impacted by timing of beverage shipments. ERICO contributed positively with sales in line with our expectations. 
Segment income increased 5%, and return on sales contracted 20 basis points to 13.3%. 3 segments delivered margin expansion greater than 100 basis points, and Valves & Controls met its first quarter income and margin commitments. 
Adjusted EPS was flat at $0.76 per share and was ahead of our guidance of $0.70 to $0.72 per share. As I mentioned previously, free cash flow started much better this year with a small usage in the quarter, and it was over $100 million improvement year-over-year. 
Now let's turn to Slide 6 for more details on Pentair's Q1 2016 performance. Our sales performance by vertical was mixed with strong growth in Residential & Commercial and in Infrastructure, which helped partially offset continued sluggishness in Energy. We saw some signs of stabilization in our Industrial businesses, and while Food & Beverage was down in the quarter, we continue to believe this vertical will deliver full year growth as shipments in our beverage business can be choppy. 
Our largest vertical, Residential & Commercial, saw 11% sales growth to start the year, led by double-digit growth in Water Quality Systems and Technical Solutions and solid growth in Flow & Filtration Solutions. Infrastructure did turn positive on strength in both North American municipal pumps and improved project activity in our Process Filtration business globally. The rate of decline within Industrial moderated for the quarter and we are encouraged by what we believe are signs of stabilization in this, our second largest vertical. 
Food & Beverage started the year slowly, impacting our Flow & Filtration Solution results, but those principal due to result of timing on beverage shipments, as I mentioned, and ongoing weakness in irrigation. 
It's no surprise that energy remains weak, and while we expected this vertical to continue to be down this year, we believe our nonenergy businesses are positioned to more than compensate for this weakness. Energy now represents just over 20% of our sales and even smaller percentage of our profits. We continue to believe the remaining 80% of our portfolio is well-positioned, particularly within Residential & Commercial and Food & Beverage verticals. 
As you can see on the right-hand side of the page, productivity remains strong and more than offset inflation. Price was a modest positive in the quarter, and ERICO contributed strength to the bottom line on strong underlying performance and synergies.
Now let's turn to Slide 7 for a review of our segment and major platform structure. We want to remind everyone on the alignment of our businesses, which we introduced at our Investor Day last November. Underneath our 4 segments, we grouped activities into 10 Strategic Business Groups, or SBGs, to better prioritize our resource allocation across the company. We'll discuss the SBG performance within each segment. For a more detailed look at each SBG, please refer to our presentation on our website from the 2015 Investor Day. 
Our Water business is split between 2 segments, with Flow & Filtration Solutions focused around a solutions approach and Water Quality Systems business online by product distribution. Technical Solutions has 3 well-positioned electrical businesses, and we've realigned our Valves & Controls business around 2 key selling motions, aftermarket and projects. The key distinction on all of these SBGs is that we can differentiate investments more clearly between them. 
Now let's turn to Slide 8 for a look at Water Quality Systems performance in Q1. Water Quality Systems delivered another strong quarter with 9% core sales growth. The Aquatics & Environmental Systems business grew 13% organically as the North American pool season got off to a strong start and aquaculture continue to grow nicely. 
Water Filtration grew core sales 5%, with particular strength continuing in our Residential Filtration business. 
Segment income grew an impressive 19%, and return on sales expanded 170 basis points to 18.6%. Robust operating leverage was a key contributor to margin expansion in the quarter, even as we increased our growth investments to maintain the strong momentum that Water Quality Systems have delivered the past several years.
Now let's move to Slide 8 for a look at Flow & Filtration Solutions performance in Q1. Flow and Filtration saw revenue declined 4%, with core sales down 2% and negative FX translation of another 2%. We had anticipated the segment to return to growth in the first quarter, and while the Infrastructure growth was as expected, the Food & Beverage performance was negatively impacted by the timing of those beverage shipments. We're encouraged with double-digit order growth in beverage, but given this current state of consolidation in the beer industry in particular, choppiness in sales is expected to be a trend quarter-to-quarter in the near term. 
Water Technology saw core sales declined 1% as strength in Residential & Commercial and Infrastructure pump shipments more than offset by double-digit declines in irrigation pump shipments. We believe the strength in Residential & Commercial will continue into the seasonally strong second quarter, and the longer cycle infrastructure business will continue to grow based on the solid backlog and a strong quote funnel.
Core sales in Fluid Solutions declined 5% due to the previously mentioned delays in beverage shipments, but our precision spray business grew in the quarter. Process Filtration had good core sales growth of 4% as we continue to see momentum build from our focus on industrial water reuse solutions and some improvement in Infrastructure, which includes a couple of desalination projects. 
Segment income grew 9%, and return on sale expanded 130 basis points to 11.7%. This was the fourth consecutive quarter of margin expansion, as our execution has improved within the segment. Still, we believe there's a long runway ahead for further margin improvement, particularly when the top line returns to growth. 
Now let's turn to Slide 10 to discuss our Technical Solutions performance in Q1. Technical Solutions reported 33% sales growth for the quarter, consisting of 5% core sales growth, a 2% headwind from FX and a 30% positive contribution from ERICO. Core sales in Enclosures declined 5% due to the pressure we saw in our short cycle industrial business late last year persisted. While the year-over-year comparisons are expected to remain challenging in the second quarter, we are encouraged to see stabilization in the daily order rate in the quarter and continue to expect easier comparisons in the back half of the year as a result. 
Thermal Management experienced impressive core sales growth of 22% as 2 projects in Canada are nearing completion. Industrial heat tracing business continues to see wins in a smaller project business while its more profitable product business remains weak. The thermal building business also had a strong quarter. 
While the results of ERICO are captured as acquisition contribution, the business performed in line with our expectations. As a reminder, over 75% of ERICO sales are into commercial end markets, which remained very healthy in the quarter. We believe we are on track to deliver over $10 million in synergies for the year on top of the base business attractive profitability. 
Segment income grew 45% and return on sales expanded an impressive 190 basis points to 21.5%. Despite negative mix in Thermal Management and some price pressures in Enclosures, strong productivity and the positive contribution from ERICO helped drive margin expansion in the quarter.
While core sales are expected to turn negative for the remainder of the year due to the 2 large thermal projects ending, we believe Technical Solutions is well-positioned to deliver strong income growth and margin expansion due in large part to strong execution with the ERICO integration and a strong culture around productivity across the whole segment. 
Now let's move to Slide 11 to discuss the Valves & Controls performance in Q1. Valves & Controls reported a 10% decline in revenue, with core sales down 7% and a 3% headwind from FX. Most importantly, the top line was in line with our expectations. Backlog was down 2% sequentially which includes negative FX translation. Core orders were down 11% year-over-year consistent with the double-digit rate of decline that's been experienced the past several quarters. Core sales were down 9% in aftermarket and down 4% in projects as the business continues to shift out of backlog. We expected aftermarket to start the year slowly as customers were finalizing their budgets, and OpEx continues to be constrained right along with the CapEx at many customers. 
In the second quarter, we'll watch closely both aftermarket sales and orders, but we remain very cautious since whether energy markets have found bottom. 
The right half of the page shows first quarter segment income and return on sales, which both met our forecast. It was just under 1 year ago when we saw an acceleration in the rate of decline in the business, and I asked John to step in and lead the business on an interim basis as we search for a new leader of the segment, which of course we just recently filled. I'm very pleased with the entire Valves & Controls leadership team's resilience during these difficult times, and I want to personally thank them for their tenacious leadership. While the business continues watching for signs of stabilization and orders, they have accomplished a lot the past several quarters in rightsizing the business to today's hard reality. We believe for some time that the downturn in energy is more than cyclical, and we've acted accordingly. Over the past 12 months, we've realigned the business to reflect the energy industry declines, resulting in headcount reductions of over 20%. It hasn't been easy, but it was necessary. I would also like to point out that these rightsizing actions were started a year ago and are on top of what we've already accomplished since we acquired the business 3.5 years ago. To put it in perspective, we reduced the number of ERPs, accounting centers and other back office functions by over 40%, and the manufacturing footprint is 30% smaller. While these are steps in the right direction, there are still more opportunity and work to be done. Under Dennis's leadership and with a strong team in place, we believe the Valves & Controls will be well-positioned for an eventual recovery in its end markets. While we expect revenue recover to be a couple of years away, we continue to take actions aimed at improving profitability even this year. 
So the 6.5% return on sales in Q1 is not indicative of our current cost structure. We expect improved margins each quarter this year as 2015's higher cost inventory works its way through the income statement in the first half. Our prior communication of $100 million in cost-out benefit in 2016 is on track, and we continue to expect to exit the year with margins in the team and full year margins just north of 10% even on muted sales. 
Now let's turn to Slide 12 for a look at the Valves & Controls backlog. As you can see on this slide, short cycle orders were down 5% and long cycle orders declined 18%. The short cycle weakness was more acute in Europe, but the U.S. also was weak as customers continue to defer maintenance. This was not just in oil and gas but also in power and mining. We watch orders closely to see when customers begin to start spending OpEx once again. 
The weakness on the project side was broad-based with CapEx budgets being cut across the board. The quoting funnel appears to be slowly improving, particularly in LNG and petrochem, but we're not expecting a big increase in orders. We continue to believe there's potential for orders to find the bottom in the second half in projects though. Second quarter orders will be instructive and seat the quote funnel begins to bear fruit and we remain cautious and interested to see if there are signs of stabilization in the short cycle business. We'll continue to focus on capitalizing on opportunities, particularly where we can leverage the breadth of the entire Valves & Controls portfolio.
Now let's move to Slide 13 to provide an update on our segment positioning. Before I turn the call over to John to discuss our outlook for the remainder of the year, I wanted to provide an update on our segment positioning and comment on the reordering of the segments. While Valves & Controls has received a lot of attention the past 18 months, the business has worked to aggressively reposition itself in the face of a significant reset in the energy industry and now the segment's expected to contribute only 15% of this year's Pentair income. We believe the other 85% of the portfolio is well-positioned and we remain excited about the opportunities in these other 3 segments. 
We have 2 high-performing segments today in Water Quality Systems and Technical Solutions. Flow & Filtration Solutions has made good progress in improving its margin and cash flow wile positioning for return to growth. This chart shows the progress against each segment's priorities. We introduced these priorities at our Investor Day last November and highlighted them once again in our 2016 outlook call last December. Both Water Quality Systems and Technical Solutions have continued to perform, and we believe they're well-positioned to build on their momentum. We're encouraged with the improvements in margin and cash flow at Flow & Filtration Solutions. And as the business continues to gain traction and moving to a solutions provider from a manufacturing component, we expect organic growth to not only return but to become more consistent and predictable given their portfolio is well aligned to grow with macro trends, particularly in Food & Beverage.
So 2016 has started off as we expected. We believe our water and electrical businesses are well-positioned to continue delivering strong results, and Valves & Controls has become a smaller piece of the portfolio as a result of the energy reset, and we are making good progress in stabilizing and rightsizing that business. Cash and earnings execution remain the mantra for 2016, and we are focused on delivering our commitments to our shareholders. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to John.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Randy. Please turn to Slide #14 titled Balance Sheet and Cash Flow. We ended the first quarter with $4.8 billion of net debt, inclusive of cash on hand. This is a slight increase from our year-end debt levels due to seasonal working capital bui
componenttext:
Thank you, Randy. Please turn to Slide #14 titled Balance Sheet and Cash Flow. We ended the first quarter with $4.8 billion of net debt, inclusive of cash on hand. This is a slight increase from our year-end debt levels due to seasonal working capital build, particularly in our Residential & Commercial businesses. As Randy mentioned earlier, our free cash flow was over $100 million better to start the year versus the comparable period last year. While we did consume minimal cash in the quarter in line with historical patterns, we continue to expect to deliver our free cash flow target of approximately $750 million for the year. 
Our ROIC ended the quarter at 9.6%. Our capital expenditure forecast remains unchanged at approximately $150 million as we continue to invest in the businesses that have earned the right to grow, especially Water Quality Systems and Technical Solutions, and drive deeper disciplines into our Valves & Controls factories.
Please turn to Slide  15 labeled Q2 2016 Pentair Outlook. For the second quarter, we expect core sales to decline approximately 3% and total sales to increase 4%, inclusive of FX headwinds and a positive contribution from ERICO. On a core sales basis, we expect Water Quality Systems to grow approximately 5% as the segment enters its seasonally strongest period. Flow & Filtration Solutions' core sales are expected to be up modestly as the business continues to reposition itself and comparisons become easier. Technical Solutions is expected to have a core sales decline of roughly 3% as 2 projects in the Thermal Management business are completed. And Enclosures faces another tough year-over-year comparison. Finally, Valves & Controls core sales are expected to decline approximately 13% as the project backlog remains weak and we remain cautious in the short-term as to whether the aftermarket business will accelerate after the slow start to the year. We are expecting segment income to increase approximately 5% and return on sales to be roughly flat at 16.5%.
Below the operating income line, we continue to expect the tax rate to remain around 20.5%, net interest and other to approximately $35 million and shares outstanding to be just over $182 million. Our second quarter adjusted EPS guidance is $1.08 to $1.11, which is an increase of approximately 2% year-over-year at the midpoint. We expect seasonal ramp-up in free cash flow and further improvement in our working capital performance.
Please turn to Slide 16 labeled Full-year 2016 Pentair Outlook. We are maintaining our full year adjusted EPS outlook of $4.05 to $4.25 with very few changes to our prior forecast. For the full year, we still expect total Pentair core sales to decline approximately 1%. Water Quality Systems full year core sales are anticipated to be up approximately 5% as both Aquatic and Environmental Systems and water filtration businesses are well-positioned to continue driving the growth rates experienced the last several years. Flow & Filtration Solutions core sales are expected to be up approximately 2% for the full year, led by stabilization in Water Technologies and growth in both Fluid Solutions and Process Filtration. Technical Solutions is expected to see core sales decline roughly 2%, which is slightly better than our prior forecast as the Thermal Management backlog has grown, and we have seen stabilization in Enclosures daily order rates. Finally, Valves & Controls core sales are still expected to decline roughly 8%, given our current view of orders for the full year.
We expect segment income to grow roughly 9%, and return on sales to expand approximately 90 basis points to 16.5%, with 3 of our 4 segments delivering full year margin expansion. We continue to anticipate full year corporate cost to be just over $90 million, net interest and other roughly $140 million and the share count to be just over 182 million, all essentially in line with previous expectations. Adjusted EPS is expected to be up approximately 5% at the midpoint of the range. Finally, we expect a strong year of free cash flow at [ph] approximately $750 million, which represents roughly 100% of our adjusted net income. 
Steve, can you please open the line for questions. Thank you.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of Steven Winoker from Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of Steven Winoker from Bernstein.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. The first one is can you maybe comment on the treasury rules and regulations that came out, particularly regarding earnings and the impact you see on Pentair's tax rate over time?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. The first one is can you maybe comment on the treasury rules and regulations that came out, particularly regarding earnings and the impact you see on Pentair's tax rate over time?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve. Still obviously processing, it's a very generic rule and now we got to look into the specificity of all of it. But in the next several years or at least the longer-term to however long we have that in place, we don't see any impact to overall
componenttext: Yes, Steve. Still obviously processing, it's a very generic rule and now we got to look into the specificity of all of it. But in the next several years or at least the longer-term to however long we have that in place, we don't see any impact to overall tax rate. But clearly, the rules would challenge acquiring North America businesses and layering on new debt onto those businesses. So we would have to take advantage of our operational synergies to get to those tax synergies that we would have. And clearly, any acquisition in the future needs to strategically fit and be an operational synergistic acquisition, and then we would look to utilize our advantaged structure to still gain that cash fluidity and then ultimately advance the tax strategies on a more permanent basis.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then there's been quite a lot of speculation, Randy, about your -- how you're positioned in Valves & Controls. Clearly, you've been improving the business, and we can see that. But part of that debate is whether Pentair is a consolidator
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then there's been quite a lot of speculation, Randy, about your -- how you're positioned in Valves & Controls. Clearly, you've been improving the business, and we can see that. But part of that debate is whether Pentair is a consolidator or a consolidatee in this business over time and what your desire is. can you maybe comment on how you're thinking about it?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, and I think there's been some confusion about that. I think it was not a secret that we saw ourselves with our structure and with this really great business that we have in Valves & Controls. As in a fragmented industry like Valves & Controls i
componenttext: Well, yes, and I think there's been some confusion about that. I think it was not a secret that we saw ourselves with our structure and with this really great business that we have in Valves & Controls. As in a fragmented industry like Valves & Controls in flow in general as a likely consolidator. And what I've said is right now we are not focused on being a consolidator, we're focused on fixing what we got. So our focus really is on continuing to get our margins back and we believe, as I mentioned in the prepared remarks, we believe we are on the road to do that. We like to see the first quarter be the [indiscernible] if you will on return on sales for the business and continue to execute because the business has a lot of headroom even without revenue, as I said, even without revenue recovery, we believe we can get back the teams and we want to prove that. I don't want to be laying stuff over it at this point.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's clear. And just a quick one. Organic growth ex those large projects, the large thermal projects in the quarter, what was that if you take those out? The big ones?
componenttext: Okay. That's clear. And just a quick one. Organic growth ex those large projects, the large thermal projects in the quarter, what was that if you take those out? The big ones?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: In Water Quality, specifically Aquatics, that's impressive core revenue growth of 13%. So looks like you got off to a strong spring selling season in pool. Anything regarding like a prebuy that happened? Are the going to be any comp issues? And how does t
componenttext: In Water Quality, specifically Aquatics, that's impressive core revenue growth of 13%. So looks like you got off to a strong spring selling season in pool. Anything regarding like a prebuy that happened? Are the going to be any comp issues? And how does this business set up for the second quarter, because it's also seasonally important?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Deane, our dealers are the pool builders, they exited last year with a pretty good backlog of pools builds, so they entered the year with a backlog of business to do. Plus we have all the rebate programs and all the advanced equipment, the Eco select
componenttext: Yes, Deane, our dealers are the pool builders, they exited last year with a pretty good backlog of pools builds, so they entered the year with a backlog of business to do. Plus we have all the rebate programs and all the advanced equipment, the Eco select line we have. So we really think it's their share gain, that's generally market, there's not a lot of prebuy. The early buy program we had was not remarkable. And so a lot of this is not the big early buy product that if you will, stocking the sell-through or normal seasonal stock in the sell-through. So we got a lot of momentum in that business, and we continue to invest in that business in sales and in new product development in order to keep the momentum going.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you have a sense of the product vitality of your pool equipment recently? Just I know you had the IntelliFlo, but just how much of that product line is new in the last 3 years?
componenttext: Do you have a sense of the product vitality of your pool equipment recently? Just I know you had the IntelliFlo, but just how much of that product line is new in the last 3 years?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I'll get the number wrong, it's close to 30% right now. And it's not just -- in fact, we have a new -- the next versions of IntelliFlo are coming now. But there's new controls, there's new LED lighting, there's new heaters, there's really a comple
componenttext: I think I'll get the number wrong, it's close to 30% right now. And it's not just -- in fact, we have a new -- the next versions of IntelliFlo are coming now. But there's new controls, there's new LED lighting, there's new heaters, there's really a complete new suite of products all aimed at sitting that Eco select sustainability mark. And as I think as you saw, we just got the third ENERGY STAR award from the EPA, which makes us a sustained sustainer. I don't think they call it . So we feel really good about that business and we got a lot more growth. And as you know, that was the basis, it was our strength there that was the basis of the foundation of our aquaculture business, which is again just managing bodies of water.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then over on the Valves & Controls side, so you've added Dennis Cassidy to the team. And I'm [indiscernible] hearing, as you bring him on board, he's coming in midstream, and that's an unfortunate pond, but he's on board when you already h
componenttext: Understood. And then over on the Valves & Controls side, so you've added Dennis Cassidy to the team. And I'm [indiscernible] hearing, as you bring him on board, he's coming in midstream, and that's an unfortunate pond, but he's on board when you already have an existing restructuring plan, existing commitments. And just what's the continuity in terms of leadership there? Was John going to be still part-time there? Or does he roll off? And should we expect any tweaking to the plan and the commitments because you said you're going to exit 2016, which will be if the math works and the teams and margins, I just want to know what kind of variability there might be with the change in leadership?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, it took us a while to find the right person for the reason that the business is facing some challenges, and we needed someone who is up to it. I'm quite excited to have Dennis, Dennis, from Alix Partners, and Alix Partners has a reputation f
componenttext: Well, I mean, it took us a while to find the right person for the reason that the business is facing some challenges, and we needed someone who is up to it. I'm quite excited to have Dennis, Dennis, from Alix Partners, and Alix Partners has a reputation for transformations and restructuring. And he has some of that experience. He also has some extraordinarily deep and successful experience doing value stream transformation in the oilfield services business, and he's deeply engaged in the energy field. So as we -- let me back up. He spent a lot of time getting to know the business and the programs that are in place, and he's totally on board with them. And he'll tweak them. And it certainly has, as President, he has full right to do that. But again, tweak -- it will be tweaked to get us to the objectives we have. One area where he will be very focused is on these 2 value streams, aftermarket and projects and tuning, if you will, the business, so that we can really focus on the aftermarket, so that if it comes back, we can gain share there. I think as we've said before, we really didn't differentiate the way we serve the aftermarket versus project. And by tuning the system, we believe that we can get growth in that market and the fact that he's intimate with the industry is really, really beneficial and he's done things like this before. As for John, he's back to being CFO full-time. And Dennis doesn't need to doesn't need his help anymore that we do get John as  CFO.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's plenty.
componenttext: And that's plenty.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Ritchie with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Ritchie with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I heard a few times in your script you guys mentioned the word stabilization, and so I want to touch on that a little bit, specifically as it relates to the order rates, what you're seeing in your front log in Industrial. And I guess what implications
componenttext: So I heard a few times in your script you guys mentioned the word stabilization, and so I want to touch on that a little bit, specifically as it relates to the order rates, what you're seeing in your front log in Industrial. And I guess what implications if anything did that have to the guidance raise you had in Tech Solutions?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can answer that, Joe, I mean very little. I think the word stabilization is really related to the fact that when we exited Q4, we saw a double-digit declines in our North American Industrial space. And clearly, Q1 became a bit quarter to see if that was
componenttext: I can answer that, Joe, I mean very little. I think the word stabilization is really related to the fact that when we exited Q4, we saw a double-digit declines in our North American Industrial space. And clearly, Q1 became a bit quarter to see if that was going to continue or start to recover in. Clearly, we achieved our expectation in Q1, but we also saw order rates in the daily basis start to, as we said, stabilize, which means becoming less worse and starting to improve on a day-to-day basis. Long way to what we say is a growth recovery, but certainly give us more confidence of the Enclosures business and also the north Industrial hitting expectations for the year. There's the tweaks to Technical Solutions are really around we continue to build a project backlog in the Industrial heat trace business. We feel really good about that backlog. It is impacting margin slightly, but we ultimately feel that project backlog will shift this year and that was our tweak to the revenue on numbers in Technical Solutions.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And was there any change to the kind of $30 million to $40 million headwind that you guys expected to see from the major projects rolling down?
componenttext: Got it. And was there any change to the kind of $30 million to $40 million headwind that you guys expected to see from the major projects rolling down?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, there isn't.
componenttext: No, there isn't.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess maybe my follow-up question just touching on V&C, so you hit your margin target for the first quarter and clearly there's a ramp in your guidance for the remainder of the year. Can you just touch on the key factors that are going to help
componenttext: Okay. And I guess maybe my follow-up question just touching on V&C, so you hit your margin target for the first quarter and clearly there's a ramp in your guidance for the remainder of the year. Can you just touch on the key factors that are going to help you get to that ramp? I think last quarter we touched on short cycle mix. There was something related to your inventories as well. Maybe touch on the factors that are going to allow you to get from the 6.5 to teens margins [indiscernible] as we progress through the year?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Randy said it very eloquently in his script, last year high inventory rolling of this year. And to help you quantify that, let's think of somewhere around $25 million of cost that needs to roll into the first half of the year, and you can think ab
componenttext: I think Randy said it very eloquently in his script, last year high inventory rolling of this year. And to help you quantify that, let's think of somewhere around $25 million of cost that needs to roll into the first half of the year, and you can think about that split between Q1 and Q2. And if you think about that as last year's coming in and we've got our cost base now in line with what we are shipping and building, you kind of see the headwinds that we are factoring in Q1 and Q2 that are no longer there in Q3 and Q4. Plus we see the acceleration of a lot of the headcount actions and people-related cost out actions come into the benefit Q3 and Q4 as well. So very little revenue expectations from a standpoint of anything beyond what's in the backlog and still assuming double-digit declines in aftermarket in Q2. And it's really about the actions we took last year and the timing of how those actions flow through between Q2, Q3 and Q4.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Tusa with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Tusa with JPMorgan.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: So I just wanted to be clear on the tax question, so is there a risk that the tax rate is going up? Or what are you kind of messaging here? Is it there's kind of a TBDs that need to be worked out? What is kind of the final message on that for now?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The simple answer is everything they've announced has nothing to do with anyone who's already got the structure, and we already got the structure, that's point one. Point two is we have to figure out what it means for things we do in the future, right now
componenttext: The simple answer is everything they've announced has nothing to do with anyone who's already got the structure, and we already got the structure, that's point one. Point two is we have to figure out what it means for things we do in the future, right now we're not doing anything because we're focused on cash and earnings execution. But when we get back to doing acquisitions, we're going to have to look to see what the impact is in terms of what's called the debt push down strategy and what they call earnings [indiscernible]. We still, whatever we do, we'll still have the opportunities to focus on operating synergies, as John said, and we'll still have the ability to move cash around freely, which is an extraordinary advantage, it doesn't get focused on as much, and our tax structure versus our former tax structure.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And you don't have to keep as you grow earnings, you don't have to keep adding intercompany debt to kind make sure that, that extra income is shielded, for a lack of a better term?
componenttext: Right. And you don't have to keep as you grow earnings, you don't have to keep adding intercompany debt to kind make sure that, that extra income is shielded, for a lack of a better term?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. On the Valves, I think you made -- I joined the call a little bit late, but I think you called the Valves recovery 2 years out. Could you just maybe expand on that a little more? Does that mean you don't expect growth until really '18? Is th
componenttext: Okay. Got it. On the Valves, I think you made -- I joined the call a little bit late, but I think you called the Valves recovery 2 years out. Could you just maybe expand on that a little more? Does that mean you don't expect growth until really '18? Is that a simple way of saying that?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we said we and it was an imprecise comment, actually and ad lib on the script. We think there's a chance that project orders will bottom out in the second half this year, which wouldn't give us growth until next year, second part of 2000 --  maybe 18
componenttext: No, we said we and it was an imprecise comment, actually and ad lib on the script. We think there's a chance that project orders will bottom out in the second half this year, which wouldn't give us growth until next year, second part of 2000 --  maybe 18 months [indiscernible]. Right now we're not subprojects start to recover in the second half, then ultimately it will give us growth about.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So can you grow in '17, do you think at this stage?
componenttext: So can you grow in '17, do you think at this stage?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we can grow in '17, aftermarket has to come back. The fact that our aftermarket is down in short cycle. Basically, there's a continuum of ongoing maintenance. There's must do, there's good to do and there's nice to do. And right now, they've
componenttext: Yes, I think we can grow in '17, aftermarket has to come back. The fact that our aftermarket is down in short cycle. Basically, there's a continuum of ongoing maintenance. There's must do, there's good to do and there's nice to do. And right now, they've taken a cleaver to all their spending and it's just bang down 40% and so they haven't really fully sorted it out, OpEx to. Now they got to get back to the must do's and the should do's but then they don't have to get back to the nice to do's. But that's what we want to be close to and help them as they sort out, now they've in-sourced things, they're going to figure out longer-term that they outsourcing things. It's very fluid.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think real quickly, just to add to what Randy said, I mean, I don't think we see or will be able to call the recovery this year, which means any growth we get will be our backlog plus modest expected growth in '17. Given where we are in the base this ye
componenttext: I think real quickly, just to add to what Randy said, I mean, I don't think we see or will be able to call the recovery this year, which means any growth we get will be our backlog plus modest expected growth in '17. Given where we are in the base this year, we would expect to grow modestly next year, continue to work the cost actions that we need to and then any long-term recovery or rapid recovery is definitely in our views beyond '17.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Just one last question just on the Flow & Filtration segment, I think that implies a relatively strong back half of the year. Is that some lumpiness in Food & Beverage? What's kind of the driver there?
componenttext: Got it. Just one last question just on the Flow & Filtration segment, I think that implies a relatively strong back half of the year. Is that some lumpiness in Food & Beverage? What's kind of the driver there?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's just Food & Beverage. I think what we got is we got a little bit of customers who have completed some consolidations, and they're a little bit more lumpier in their execution of projects and how they're running the capital flow-through. And so w
componenttext: Yes, it's just Food & Beverage. I think what we got is we got a little bit of customers who have completed some consolidations, and they're a little bit more lumpier in their execution of projects and how they're running the capital flow-through. And so while we still have a very solid backlog, we are seeing a little bit of free time in the backlog, which is impacting what quarter that ships in.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Shannon O'Callaghan from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Shannon O'Callaghan from UBS.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, on Valves & Controls, just in terms of actually hitting the forecast this quarter, that seems regardless of what the actual numbers were, it was on plan, which has been a challenge. John, can you talk about kind of the actions you took while you were
componenttext: Hey, on Valves & Controls, just in terms of actually hitting the forecast this quarter, that seems regardless of what the actual numbers were, it was on plan, which has been a challenge. John, can you talk about kind of the actions you took while you were there? And if you like changes you made to the process there are going to enable more kind of reliable delivery on forecast regardless of what those forecasts actually are?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I appreciate this, Shannon. What Randy and I are introducing and what I took into the business and we try to the discipline is, there's known ways to think of project execution and working long cycle business and project backlog. You start out with t
componenttext: Yes, I appreciate this, Shannon. What Randy and I are introducing and what I took into the business and we try to the discipline is, there's known ways to think of project execution and working long cycle business and project backlog. You start out with the shippable backlog, and then you get  you look at standard deviation and what's going to happen between being pushed out or pulled in. Customers are always going to you. But if you look at that over a period of time, it's always a percentage of the backlog. And what happens is people work deep in the business is they have a lot of hope in their forecast, that everything is going to be good and nothing bad is going to happen. And so when you take a look at it a high level, we decided to take out those stretches from the expectations and really build on the precision of what's going to get shipped out on a weekly basis and I really think that muscles now been developed and built within the team, and I'm very proud of what they accomplished, as Randy mentioned, and I think we're going to be much more predicable as we go forward. So that's what I would say.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd add in compliments to you, John. I mean, if you look at the algorithms, there was not great coordination between the sales forecast, the operating forecast and the materials forecast and the finance forecast. They were not, as you said, they were assu
componenttext: I'd add in compliments to you, John. I mean, if you look at the algorithms, there was not great coordination between the sales forecast, the operating forecast and the materials forecast and the finance forecast. They were not, as you said, they were assumptions but I mean John really streamlined that, got people talking and we have high-quality forecast now. This is the second quarter, I mean we hit the first quarter [ph].

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a long way away perfect process, but I think we're our way to getting the expectations aligned and therefore not trying to have anticipated production against demand that's not needed.
componenttext: So a long way away perfect process, but I think we're our way to getting the expectations aligned and therefore not trying to have anticipated production against demand that's not needed.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That helps. And then just a little follow-up on the stabilization in Enclosures. You talked about exiting last year down double digits then getting less negative. Are we turning positive yet? Or when do you expect it to return positive? Maybe just a
componenttext: Okay. That helps. And then just a little follow-up on the stabilization in Enclosures. You talked about exiting last year down double digits then getting less negative. Are we turning positive yet? Or when do you expect it to return positive? Maybe just a little bit more of the cadence.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't turned positive yet. So what we're saying is, if we stay at the level we're at, when we start lapping the second half, it will -- the comps will be -- the comps will look better. But we're not -- I would call out along the bottom, maybe.
componenttext: No, we haven't turned positive yet. So what we're saying is, if we stay at the level we're at, when we start lapping the second half, it will -- the comps will be -- the comps will look better. But we're not -- I would call out along the bottom, maybe.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We think we get back to flattish as we exit Q3 and maybe some slight increase in Q4, Shannon.
componenttext: We think we get back to flattish as we exit Q3 and maybe some slight increase in Q4, Shannon.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Halloran from Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Halloran from Baird.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just continuing that thought process. When you think about stabilization beyond just the Enclosures piece, are you at the point where you're starting to see a little bit more normal sequential patterns to the year? And when you get towards the back hal
componenttext: So just continuing that thought process. When you think about stabilization beyond just the Enclosures piece, are you at the point where you're starting to see a little bit more normal sequential patterns to the year? And when you get towards the back half of the year, is there any fundamental improvement embedded in some of those kind of core industrial markets? Or is it just following that normal sequential pattern?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we are getting back to sort of more normal expectations. I think one of the learnings for everybody is that when energy business spends $1 trillion a year and goes down $600 million a year, the knock-on effect in many other industries is pretty pr
componenttext: I think we are getting back to sort of more normal expectations. I think one of the learnings for everybody is that when energy business spends $1 trillion a year and goes down $600 million a year, the knock-on effect in many other industries is pretty profound, and that's really what's I think is the core driver of a lot of what we call it industrial, but sort of the second-order effect is the cut from the energy business. And so those are getting sorted out. I mean, people are adjusting the reality at this new level, and so I think we'll see more seasonality. And as John said, we are hopeful that there would be an increase in the fourth quarter. We typically would see a bump in the fourth quarter for Industrial.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the aftermarket side, you guys talked about in-sourcing versus outsourcing before and obviously still competitive out there. But when you think about what the competition's doing, not so much of the larger valves guys but some of the smaller v
componenttext: And then on the aftermarket side, you guys talked about in-sourcing versus outsourcing before and obviously still competitive out there. But when you think about what the competition's doing, not so much of the larger valves guys but some of the smaller valve guys, are you -- what are you seeing with them and what are you seeing your customers doing? Is there a migration towards some of the lower-cost guys at this point and how are you defending core share?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are certainly looking out for that, I think what's happening right now is dynamic. First of all, we got the cut back of OpEx because it's a spend. But the downstream right now is where all the cash is being generated for our customers' customers, and t
componenttext: We are certainly looking out for that, I think what's happening right now is dynamic. First of all, we got the cut back of OpEx because it's a spend. But the downstream right now is where all the cash is being generated for our customers' customers, and they're running them fallout, bring cash into the organization, and so there's a lot of the deferrals are still happening because we don't have the plant shutdown we used to happen. As Randy mentioned, you can do after so long and then ultimately you do the shutdown. Now we haven't assumed any recovery in Q2 in that pattern and we are thinking that, that's more likely a Q3 event.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just from that perspective, what do you guys need to see besides time? Is there anything specific? Or is it just time needs to push on and then these guys could come back to the market again?
componenttext: And just from that perspective, what do you guys need to see besides time? Is there anything specific? Or is it just time needs to push on and then these guys could come back to the market again?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean what they need to do, our customers need to adjust to the fact that this may not recover soon. So they have to adjust their own operating practices. So I mean, it's not just a maintenance. But the first thing you do when you have a downturn l
componenttext: Well, I mean what they need to do, our customers need to adjust to the fact that this may not recover soon. So they have to adjust their own operating practices. So I mean, it's not just a maintenance. But the first thing you do when you have a downturn like this is before you lay people off, you in-source everything. You can end up bringing maintenance in-house. And then when you start realizing that, that's not a sufficient as if I have a contractor do it, you end up doing it out more aggressively. I mean, it's not a mystery. I mean, this is what we expect. So we want to be in a position, that's one of the reasons why we want to focus more in Valves & Controls on the aftermarket value stream, so that we can be in a position to be that provider on valves because of the -- with the breadth of our product line and the service centers we have, we can be more aggressive as they make that next step, and they haven't gotten to the next step yet.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Graham with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Graham with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is more of a question for John. You guys are looking to do a lot in your footprint rationalization plans over the next several years. I was just wondering if you can kind of give us a bit more in the metrics, factories distribution centers closed, th
componenttext: This is more of a question for John. You guys are looking to do a lot in your footprint rationalization plans over the next several years. I was just wondering if you can kind of give us a bit more in the metrics, factories distribution centers closed, things that are in processing and what have you. I know you said that you feel good, on track there, but it's still early, and just wondering if you can share some more metrics with us?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So to put that in perspective right now, we have 29 factories in Valves & Controls. And we have announced the closure of maybe 2 to 3. Well, 3. I think we're focused right now on making sure that we've got good standard work, and that we've got good
componenttext: Yes. So to put that in perspective right now, we have 29 factories in Valves & Controls. And we have announced the closure of maybe 2 to 3. Well, 3. I think we're focused right now on making sure that we've got good standard work, and that we've got good documentation as we in generally do, because moving these factories is not very easy. So I don't think we're going to announce or discuss substantial factory reductions over the next several years. I think where the big opportunity is and where Dennis is focusing is how do we improve the linearization within a quarter of how we are shipping, how do we reduce the inefficiencies, these are all great tools that lean brings that tool to the table. And I think as far as the distribution and the outside service centers, we have 43 independent service centers that aren't part of a current distribution center or customers factory. I think the customers going to help define that for us over the next 3 to 4 years because moving in-house into their operations is where we see it going because eliminating that brick-and-mortar between us and them seems to be where the industry is heading. So can't give you specifics, but I think there's an opportunities in both of those areas. But I'd say on the factory side, I wouldn't expect there many closures for the next several years, talked about optimization.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. My follow-up is about the Valves & Controls split of revenues where you guys are calling that business essentially half aftermarket and MRO. And every valves company has their fair share of standard products. So it just seems like half of the
componenttext: Fair enough. My follow-up is about the Valves & Controls split of revenues where you guys are calling that business essentially half aftermarket and MRO. And every valves company has their fair share of standard products. So it just seems like half of the business coming from the aftermarket just seems like a pretty high number because typically when a standard valves sales, the end users essentially cuts it out and throws it in the garbage. So I'm just kind of wondering, is it possible that there is some CapEx from your customers in your aftermarket?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me -- it is aftermarket standard product, because you can't tell the difference, particularly if it's sold in the U.S. it's heavy distribution. If you got a standard Keystone butterfly valve and it's sitting in stock, if it's going in a new installati
componenttext: Let me -- it is aftermarket standard product, because you can't tell the difference, particularly if it's sold in the U.S. it's heavy distribution. If you got a standard Keystone butterfly valve and it's sitting in stock, if it's going in a new installation and replacement, you can't tell the difference. So but it's the same selling motion. So to be precise, we put aftermarket standard product together as in the same selling motion because there is an urgency and an intimacy that you need with the customer in order to win. And we haven't had -- we haven't had that clearer focus on it, and that will help both the aftermarket service valves and the standard group replacement valves. When you get into an engineer valve, it's closer to project selling motion. So we'll try to be more precise..

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That sounds much more specific. Would you say the standard valve product, which is essentially a CapEx item, is that maybe half of the MRO?
componenttext: That sounds much more specific. Would you say the standard valve product, which is essentially a CapEx item, is that maybe half of the MRO?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it isn't always a CapEx stuff. [indiscernible] operating expense dollar and the CapEx expense dollar is how the accountants treat it. To me it's money spent and then different people control it, I mean. So I don't mean to be flip, but the operating
componenttext: Well, it isn't always a CapEx stuff. [indiscernible] operating expense dollar and the CapEx expense dollar is how the accountants treat it. To me it's money spent and then different people control it, I mean. So I don't mean to be flip, but the operating expenses to run a refinery or petrochem plant, they're enormous. And so and a lot of it looks very much like, particularly in the standard valves side, it looks the same. I think a lot of people, including us, we are surprised by how much the OpEx spending was impacted given was the CapEx that was intended to be cut, but it's a blunt weapon, and we all know that from our own. When we have to crank down costs, it's cranking down costs. We don't differentiate when there's an urgency about it. And then we get better, right. We said we got to put more into the efficiency of the existing plants, and we've already cut as many projects as we can. So I don't mean to go down to the depths here, but that's all I got.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if you wouldn't mind if I could just hack this one on. Can you tell us at all how April is looking outside of Valves & Controls?
componenttext: I'm just wondering if you wouldn't mind if I could just hack this one on. Can you tell us at all how April is looking outside of Valves & Controls?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we don't do that.
componenttext: No, we don't do that.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: I mean it's all incorporated in Q2 guide.

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Starting in Water Quality, some very nice margin expansion there. But Randy, you also mentioned increased growth investments. Can you talk about the kind of investments that you're making there and perhaps quantify the increased headwind? I know you're al
componenttext: Starting in Water Quality, some very nice margin expansion there. But Randy, you also mentioned increased growth investments. Can you talk about the kind of investments that you're making there and perhaps quantify the increased headwind? I know you're always making growth investments, but maybe the increased headwinds to margins in the quarter?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We talked a lot about investing in products, which we're doing both in Residential Filtration, a lot in Foodservice, which is a really attractive business and on the pool side. But in addition to that, we're making investments on the sales coverage side o
componenttext: We talked a lot about investing in products, which we're doing both in Residential Filtration, a lot in Foodservice, which is a really attractive business and on the pool side. But in addition to that, we're making investments on the sales coverage side on our Residential Filtration business. We moved Residential Filtration to Karl Frykman and his Water Quality team about 18 months ago. And what we want to do is we want to replicate what we've done in pool in Residential Filtration business. And we're the largest maker of products and components for water treatment and water filtration in the world for residential. We're the largest. But we don't have the same kind of customer intimacy that we have in the pool business that's turned into such a sweet business for us. We believe the residential has the same potential for us. So what Karl and his team is done is they're replicating the kind of coverage, the direct dealer coverage on the other side of distribution in order to drive brand and drive product adoption and get customer intimacy and get voice of the customer back to our product. So a lot of the investments are actually on the sales side, and that's global. And we're doing it in the United States, doing it in Europe and Canada, less so in different kind of coverage investment [indiscernible] in the emerging markets. But I'm quite excited about the early returns on that. I don't think it's really affected our numbers yet, but it is given us great insight. And I'm expecting great things.

componenttext: That's helpful. Second one is on the Enclosures business. You talked about industrial stabilizing, but there's also a bit couple of mentions of some price pressure in Enclosures. Is that something you expect to continue as Industrial stabilize the pricing pressure eases? just how you're thinking about that?

headline: Pentair plc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. One of the things we're seeing is we've been more aggressive on Enclosures side going back after what we would call modified standard product. And there is a little more pricing pressure in that, and that's what we're really seeing there. Plus there
componenttext: Yes. One of the things we're seeing is we've been more aggressive on Enclosures side going back after what we would call modified standard product. And there is a little more pricing pressure in that, and that's what we're really seeing there. Plus there isn't a lot of commodity inflation, so there's not really a lot of price being passed on, on the standard side. So we are not assuming we're going to bounce back to get in the 1 to 2 points of price, but we don't think it's a systemic issue.

componenttext: Yes. So I'll hit valves first. I mean, we said that we expected roughly 4 points of price for the year, and that includes standard product, which is not a lot of price, and then margin compression coming from the project side. And I would say that, that's still the right forecast. I think we hope that, that would be a little bit conservative. I think right now that's playing out to be realistic. On the rest of the portfolio, very, very modest as far as what pricing we can get across the general portfolio, areas of 2-step distribution we have normal price increases, we are seeing it. But for the most part, the low inflation material, which we are recognize material productivity is leading to a more flattish pricing environment globally.

componenttext: I think you're seeing, in Q1, you see kind of by segment what the prices could be breaking out. And I think we expect that rate of price increases to be what we think for the rest of the year. But I think the inflation starts to become a little bit more on the raw material side as we move into Q3 and Q4, we're expecting some modest inflation in the back half of the year, which then would lead to what does the pricing cycle look like for 2017.

componenttext: Yes. I think the linearity of the cash flow, first of all, great Q1, and I think linearity looks a lot like last year. So it is the opportunity and now we got to get after it and make it a realized benefit in '16.

componenttext: I'll real quick. I mean, first of all, we did see a recovery in China in Q1. Was nice see, so we saw a recapture of our normal sort of double-digit growth rates in China space. Europe is stable, modest growth, single-digit core growth in Europe, and we had strong shipments in North America in the Water Quality side. So overall, I mean, I think the developed regions are doing well in that space, as you expect and then doing pretty well and seeing some recovery in China as we add new distributors and we work on different distribution channels.
