headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Emily, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Pentair Q2 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Jim Lucas, you may begin your conference.
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Emily, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Pentair Q2 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Jim Lucas, you may begin your conference.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Emily, and welcome to Pentair's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. We're glad you could join us. I'm Jim Lucas, Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategic Planning. With me today is Randy Hogan, our Chairman and Chief Executive
componenttext:
Thanks, Emily, and welcome to Pentair's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. We're glad you could join us. I'm Jim Lucas, Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategic Planning. With me today is Randy Hogan, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Stauch, our Chief Financial Officer.
On today's call, we will provide details on our second quarter 2016 performance as well as our third quarter and full year 2016 outlook as outlined in this morning's release.
Before we begin, let me remind you that any statements made about the company's anticipated financial results are forward-looking statements subject to future risks and uncertainties, such as the risks outlined in Pentair's most recent 10-K and today's release.
Forward-looking statements included herein are made as of today, and the company undertakes no obligation to update publicly such statements to reflect subsequent events or circumstances. Actual results could differ materially from anticipated results.
Today's webcast is accompanied by a presentation, which can be found in the Investors section of Pentair's website. We will reference these slides throughout our prepared remarks. Any reference to non-GAAP financials are reconciled in the appendix of the presentation. We will be sure to reserve time for questions and answers after our prepared remarks.
[Operator Instructions] 
I will now turn the call over to Randy.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. and good morning, everyone. I'm starting on Page 4. We were pleased with our second quarter results, which came in at the high end of our expectations. The top line was consistent with our forecast, and incoming margins were slightly better t
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. and good morning, everyone. I'm starting on Page 4. We were pleased with our second quarter results, which came in at the high end of our expectations. The top line was consistent with our forecast, and incoming margins were slightly better than expectations, driven by strong execution and continued benefit from our cost-out actions. The integration of ERICO is meeting our expectations. We remain on track to meet or exceed the $10 million in synergies we targeted. Free cash flow was once again a positive story, and we're very pleased with our performance here. For the first half of the year, we generated $304 million in free cash, which is over $150 million better than what we delivered in the first half last year.
We're updating our full year adjusted EPS outlook to a range of $4.05 to $4.20, which is bringing $0.05 off the top end of the range. While Valves & Controls are starting to become more predictable, we're seeing a negative impact of sales mix in both Flow and Filtration Solutions and Technical Solutions.
Now let's turn to Slide 5 for a discussion of our Q2 2016 results. Second quarter core sales declined 1%, which is slightly better than our previously communicated expectations. Water Quality Systems delivered solid growth once again against the tough comparison, while Flow & Filtration Solutions felt the impact of continued difficult agriculture markets. 
The decline in Valves & Controls sales moderated, and Technical Solutions was flat compared to our expectation for slight decline in the quarter. ERICO contributed positively with sales in line with expectations. Segment income increased 7%, and return on sales expanded 30 basis points to 16.8%. Water Quality Systems saw a 200 basis point expansion, and Valves & Controls slightly beat second quarter income and margin commitments, which were big steps up from the first quarter. Adjusted EPS grew 3% to $1.11 per share and was at the high-end of our guidance of $1.08 to $1.11. As I mentioned previously, free cash flow was very strong in the quarter. 
Now let's turn to Slide 6 for more detail on Pentair's Q2. Our sales performance was mixed by vertical with strong growth in Residential & Commercial and Infrastructure. We saw signs of stabilization in Industrial where the rate of decline continued to moderate, and Energy did not get worse. Food & Beverage was down in the quarter due to ongoing declines in agriculture we believe our beverage business remains healthy. Our largest vertical, Residential & Commercial, saw 2% sales growth with strength in residential and Water Quality Systems and ongoing strength in commercial in both Flow & Filtration Solutions and Technical Solutions. While ERICO's performance is not captured in core results yet, a commercial markets remained solid for it, too. Infrastructure was positive once again led by continued growth in both North American municipal pumps and improved project activity in Process filtration globally. We've been looking for Flow & Filtration Solutions as the Infrastructure growth this year, which has played out as expected, and we're encouraged that bidding activity remains healthy as well. 
The rate of decline within Industrial moderated further, and we believe that this, our second largest vertical, appears to have found the bottom. Though we're not looking for a second half rebound, comparisons eased in the second half and should help reported results.
Food & Beverage declined for the second consecutive quarter as Flow & Filtration Solutions continue to feel the impact of agriculture markets that declined in the double-digit rate for us. Energy declined in a low double-digit rate for the second consecutive quarter, though we expect Energy sales to find a bottom in the second half based on the bottoming in sequential orders we've experienced. As you can see on the right-hand side of the page, productivity remain strong and more than offset inflation. ERICO contributes strength to the bottom line and strong underlying performance in synergies.
Now let's turn to Slide 7 for a look at Water Quality Systems performance in Q2. Water Quality Systems delivered another strong quarter with 3% core sales growth. While the growth rate declined sequentially with a tough comparison as the second quarter last year reflected slightly different timing in the North American Pool season than what we're experiencing this year. While the timing is different to believe the North American Pool season remains very healthy. Water filtration grew core sales 1% as both our Residential Filtration business and our Foodservice business faced tough comps. Segment income grew an impressive 11%, and return on sales expanded 200 basis points to 24.7%. Robust operating leverage was a key contributor to margin expansion in the quarter. Timing of growth investments may mute the rate of margin expansion in the second half, but we anticipate the prospects remain strong for Water Quality Systems.
Now let's move to Slide 8 for a look at Flow & Filtration Solutions.
Flow & Filtration saw core sales declined 1%. We had anticipated the segment to return to growth in the second quarter. And all the Infrastructure growth came through as expected, the Food & Beverage performance was negatively impacted by very challenging agriculture sales. Water technologies core sales declined 3% as strength in Residential & Commercial and Infrastructure pump shipments were more than offset by double-digit decline in the irrigation pump shipments. This is very similar to what we saw last quarter in this business. While we expect both the Residential & Commercial and Infrastructure businesses to see continued growth, irrigation headwinds will likely persist as comparisons remain challenging, given the drought conditions in the west that helped our sales last year. 
Core sales in Fluid Solutions declined 3%, while beverage returned to growth in the quarter and experienced strong orders growth as well. The precision business was negatively impacted by the beleaguered agriculture markets. Process filtration saw core sales growth of 10% as we continue to see momentum build from our focus on Industrial water reuse solutions and a return to growth and Infrastructure with some desalination investments. This business has some lumpiness, given the timing of projects, but we believe we continue to gain momentum from our focus on industrial water reuse.
Segment income and return on sales contracted modestly as negative mix weighed on the segment's results. We believe this is just a pause in the margin improvement journey in Flow & Filtration Solutions and still a long runway ahead for further margin growth.
Now let's turn to Slide 9 to discuss our Technical Solutions performed in the second quarter. Technical Solutions reported 32% sales growth for the quarter, consisting of flat core sales growth and 1% headwind from FX and a 34% positive contribution from ERICO. Core sales and enclosures declined 5%. encouraged by the stabilization daily order rate, which reinforces our view to easier comparisons in the back half of the year.
Thermal Management delivered core sales growth of 7%, helped in part by 2 projects in Canada that we previously discussed that are reaching completion. We have talked of this year about our Industrial heat tracing business continuing to win small projects, but unfortunately, we're seeing no sign of downstream MRO spending growth return yet. While the results of ERICO are captured as acquisition contribution, the business performed in line with our expectations. As a reminder, over 75% of ERICO sales are into commercial end markets, which remained very healthy in the quarter. We remain on track to deliver over $10 million in synergies for the year on top of the base business profitability which is performing as expected.
Segment income grew 30%, while return on sales contracted 60 basis points to 20.6%. The margin contraction was isolated to our Thermal Management businesses as the the growth we mentioned in projects versus higher-margin MRO product sales negatively impacted mix. ERICO's performed as we had anticipated and closures are seeing signs of stabilization. The performance of these 2 was not enough in the quarter to offset the impact of the negative mix experienced in the Thermal Management on the ROS.
We're not expecting downstream MRO spending to rebound in the second half. We expect this will undoubtedly have an impact on third quarter margins for Technical Solutions. So with ERICO and Enclosures performing as expected, Technical Solutions remain well positioned long term.
Now let's move to Slide 10 to discuss the Valves & Controls performance in Q2. For the second consecutive quarter, Valves & Controls met or beat its forecast for both sales and margins. Even more, the heavy lifting we've done to rightsize the cost structure of the business read out in the nice gain in margin sequentially, and orders appear to have stabilized. Valves & Controls reported a 13% decline in revenue with core sales down 11% and a 2% headwind from FX. Backlog was down 7% sequentially, which includes negative FX translation. Core orders were down 27% year-over-year against the tough comparison but as stated, we did see a flattening of orders sequentially.
Core sales were down 6% in aftermarket and down 17% in projects. In line with our expectations, the aftermarket business remained weak as OpEx continue to be constrained along with CapEx at many customers. We believe the order funnel overall is beginning to strengthen, which reinforces our view that orders have bottomed in the second quarter and will begin to expand near double-digit rates sequentially starting in the third quarter. 
The right half of the page shows second quarter segment income and return on sales, which both met our forecasts. Return on sales of 10.1% was slightly ahead of our forecast and up significantly from the first quarter as our cost-out benefit registered in line with our previously communicated expectations.
The Valves & Controls team has done courageous job in realigning the business to reflect a significant Energy industry reset. They've executed in the cost side leading the business with the opportunities that exists today and over the next several years. We continue to believe that Valves & Controls is well positioned for an eventual recovery in its end markets beginning in 2017 and will continue to enjoy rising margins sequentially even before that.
Now let's move to Slide 11 for a look at Valves & Controls backlog. Much of the backlog decline we saw has come as a result of the progress we're making in reducing our past dues. Last year, we booked roughly $100 million in orders from projects greater than $5 million. However, we've not booked even 1 order greater than $5 million during the first half of 2016. Yet orders have bottomed out sequentially. And as our customers sort out their spending plans, we expect to see a return of some larger projects. So we believe that the second quarter marks the bottom for orders, and we're expecting orders to improve in the second half of the year from their depressed first half levels. For the past 3 quarters, the business has improved its forecasting capabilities. And with aftermarket now approximating 55% of orders, that should improve the margin mix. We're encouraged with Valves & Controls meeting or beating its forecast on sales, orders and income for the second consecutive quarter. There's been tremendous progress made on rightsizing the cost structure of the business and better alignment between sales and operations has improve the forecasting and executionability of the segment. We believe the order funnel will continue to strengthen. And while the top line will not show it right away, orders bottoming and margin improving show brighter days ahead.
With that, I'll turn the call over to John.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Randy. Please turn to Slide #12 titled Balance Sheet and Cash Flow. We ended the second quarter with $4.6 billion of net debt inclusive of cash in hand. This was an improvement from where we ended the year as we used our strong cash flows in th
componenttext:
Thank you, Randy. Please turn to Slide #12 titled Balance Sheet and Cash Flow. We ended the second quarter with $4.6 billion of net debt inclusive of cash in hand. This was an improvement from where we ended the year as we used our strong cash flows in the quarter to reduce our debt levels. As Randy mentioned earlier, free cash flow increased over $150 million during the first half of the year versus the comparable period last year. We continue to expect to deliver free cash flow greater than adjusted net income for the full year.
Our ROIC ended the quarter at 9.6%. Our forecast for capital expenditures remains $150 million as we continue to invest in businesses that have earned the right to grow and drive standardization of productivity across the enterprise. We remain focused on generating strong cash flow and further debt reduction.
Please turn to Slide 13 labeled Q3 2016 Pentair outlook. For the third quarter, we expect core sales to be flat and total sales to increase 7% inclusive of FX headwinds and a positive contribution from ERICO. As a reminder, we closed on the purchase of ERICO just before the end of Q3 last year. And starting in Q4, ERICO will be included in the core. On a core basis, we expect Water Quality Systems to grow approximately 8%, while Flow & Filtration Solutions is expected to see core sales decline approximately 1%. Technical Solutions is expected to be flat on a core basis, and Valves & Controls is anticipated to see core sales decline 6%. We expect segment income to increase approximately 11% and return on sales to expand roughly 60 basis points to 16.7%. Below the operating line, we continue to expect the tax rate to remain around 20.5%, net interest and other to approximate $35 million and shares outstanding to be around 183 million. We expect free cash flow to continue to be strong during the quarter.
Please turn to Slide 14 labeled Full Year 2016 Pentair Outlook. As Randy mentioned at the beginning of the call, we've taken $0.05 off at the top end of our range, and our full year adjusted EPS outlook is no $4.05 to $4.20. For the full year, we expect core sales to decline 1%. Water Quality Systems full year core sales are anticipated to be up approximately 6%, which is slightly better than our prior forecast. We now expect Flow & Filtration Solutions to see our core sales decline of 1% versus our prior forecast of modest growth for the full year. Technical Solutions core sales is expected to be flat for the full year, which is slightly better than our prior forecast. Finally, Valves & Controls expected to see core sales decline of approximately 9%. 
We expect segment income to grow roughly 8% and return on sales to expand approximately 70 basis points to 16.3%. Our revised forecast factors in slightly better operating performance from Water Quality Systems and Valves & Controls while Technical Solutions of Flow & Filtration Solutions are expected to see margins impacted by negative mix related to unfavorable market conditions. We anticipate full year corporate cost to be just under $90 million, net interest and other of roughly $140 million and the share count to be roughly 183 million. Adjusted EPS is expected to grow approximately 5% in the midpoint of the range. Finally, we remain on track to generate free cash flow in excess of adjusted net income for the full year.
Emily, can you please open the line for questions?

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to comment about speculation. If we had anything to say, we would have said it. But I'm very pleased with the progress. There's a lot of doubters. There are doubters in a lot of places how well our actions would read out, and I think this wa
componenttext: I'm not going to comment about speculation. If we had anything to say, we would have said it. But I'm very pleased with the progress. There's a lot of doubters. There are doubters in a lot of places how well our actions would read out, and I think this was a roving quarter. And to go from the margins we had in the first quarter to the second quarter and see the bottoming of orders, I'd say valves is a lot -- has a lot clearer future today than it had in the first quarter.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Shannon, I would add to this is a great business in a difficult market condition. And 2014, we're nearly 17% margins and roughly $400 million in segment income. And what we feel like it's a trough year, we're still going to be 11.5% ROS so. Okay. We'
componenttext: Yes, Shannon, I would add to this is a great business in a difficult market condition. And 2014, we're nearly 17% margins and roughly $400 million in segment income. And what we feel like it's a trough year, we're still going to be 11.5% ROS so. Okay. We're slugging through it. I mean, obviously, seeing some sequentially bottom of the orders is a good sign. And seeing the order funnels start to become more robust in Q3 and Q4 give us excitement that we can feel like we can start contributing more and more as we go forward in Valves & Controls.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just within Valves & Controls but even technical and more broadly, some things you're saying are bottoming. You talked about, I think, within valves potential double-digit order increase sequentially in 3Q, but there's other things li
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just within Valves & Controls but even technical and more broadly, some things you're saying are bottoming. You talked about, I think, within valves potential double-digit order increase sequentially in 3Q, but there's other things like downstream. You said you assume you'll not expecting any recovery. I guess where do you expect sequential recovery, and where do you think the market is still going to remain depressed?

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a weird time. I mean there's such a mix geographically and between verticals in terms of the growing and non-growing, and I think it reflects the greater uncertainty in the world. We feel really good about the Industrial and commercial. We feel like
componenttext: It's a weird time. I mean there's such a mix geographically and between verticals in terms of the growing and non-growing, and I think it reflects the greater uncertainty in the world. We feel really good about the Industrial and commercial. We feel like infrastructures has come back with some momentum as I mentioned the orders, not knowing the sales up but orders activities remained up. And while the agriculture continued muted spending in agriculture muted our Food & Beverage look, we feel really good about Foodservice and beverage overall. So we think a lot about what individuals are spending money on. This is good, Residential & Commercial, Food & Beverage and even in Industrial. The fact that we're getting to the point where we're seeing flattened daily order rates in Industrial tells us that that's why we're seeing the bottom there. We still don't expect it to increase a lot in the second half.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Deane Dray from RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Deane Dray from RBC.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Randy, I was hoping you could expand on a comment you made in your opening remarks regarding the negative sales mix. I think you addressed it, particularly on the Valves & Controls business, but it would be interesting hearing where else you're seeing a n
componenttext: Randy, I was hoping you could expand on a comment you made in your opening remarks regarding the negative sales mix. I think you addressed it, particularly on the Valves & Controls business, but it would be interesting hearing where else you're seeing a negative mix as a relates to customers in this environment instead of buying such and such that they're opting for either a cheaper replacement, but how does it translate into customer behavior into a negative mix this quarter?

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for asking that so I could clarify. it's not -- the mix we're seeing is not mix between a customer saying buying a lower margin, lower performing product for the same application. It's specifically in Flow & Filtration. Our ag business has hig
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for asking that so I could clarify. it's not -- the mix we're seeing is not mix between a customer saying buying a lower margin, lower performing product for the same application. It's specifically in Flow & Filtration. Our ag business has higher margins than our Residential & Commercial business. And so when ag goes down and residential goes up, we've got a negative mix. So it isn't product substitution i application, it's just a mix of what's a growing and what isn't. And in the thermal business, in Technical Solutions, again products MRO has high margins projects doesn't. So we actually expected MRO to come back. Maybe that was Pollyanna-ish, probably was, but it didn't end. And therefore, all the projects that we were happy about winning kind of overwhelmed margins for thermal.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to clarify when you say you referenced ag, this is irrigation pumps that you're primarily exposed to?
componenttext: And just to clarify when you say you referenced ag, this is irrigation pumps that you're primarily exposed to?

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's 2 pieces, and they're both in flow and filtration that we're talking about that are seeing big negatives. One is irrigation and year-over-year -- it held up pretty well last year because we have pretty high share where there were droughts, and the
componenttext: There's 2 pieces, and they're both in flow and filtration that we're talking about that are seeing big negatives. One is irrigation and year-over-year -- it held up pretty well last year because we have pretty high share where there were droughts, and there was a lot of activity to drill new wells because of the drought. We don't have that impact of this year. And the second is in crop spray where we've had we've actually been whistling to the graveyard a little bit because we've been not declining as fast as the market. And this is largely OEMs and distribution where precision spray systems that are used in agriculture as well, and that market remains depressed.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on -- as an unrelated topic, we had the opportunity last month to see Pentair's attractive new business in China for residential water treatment. So this is a brand-new market for us to see, and estimates put it like 20% to 30% growth annually. A
componenttext: And then on -- as an unrelated topic, we had the opportunity last month to see Pentair's attractive new business in China for residential water treatment. So this is a brand-new market for us to see, and estimates put it like 20% to 30% growth annually. And you all have been recognized as one of the leaders in this business basically many RO systems for home appliances that are being bought by the rising middle class who just can't drink the water without boiling it. So I haven't seen you talk about this opportunity before but we saw it. Everyone is talking about it. Maybe you can talk about the opportunity is, how it fits, what the ramp is, and what kind of contribution you should expect.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I probably should talk about it more. I'll stop fighting fires. The -- what's really interesting is that there is much more awareness about the importance of safe clean water among the middle class in the developing world as there is in the U.S. and Europ
componenttext: I probably should talk about it more. I'll stop fighting fires. The -- what's really interesting is that there is much more awareness about the importance of safe clean water among the middle class in the developing world as there is in the U.S. and Europe. Now for sad reasons, there is increasing orders in the U.S. We saw a bump in the U.S. because of concern about drinking water and cities and schools, and you can see that in our orders. And we are the largest provider of equipment for residential water treatment infiltration in the world. That business has been growing nicely. It's a little bit in China. We do have nice exposure there it has been lumpy because a lot of our distribution and it's been as credit has been hard to get there. Some of our distributors had to slow down. But if you take a look at it over the last few years, it has been growing very, very substantially. I moved that business to Karl and his team a couple of years ago because we're the largest player in that business, but we weren't the best performing in that business. And we made huge progress under Carl's leadership in taking that water filtration. It's in water filtration. Water filtration is made up of that Residential & Commercial, and the Foodservice piece the brand, if you will. And a lot of the margin expansion you saw on is actually because of the momentum we're gaining there. And we'll talk more about it.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Steve Winoker from Bernstein.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Steve Winoker from Bernstein.

componenttextpreview: Can you maybe talk a little bit through the progress making in flow and filtration and kind of it's still early days in many ways, but just talk about where you are in that path and how the quarter as you sort of look forward where do you think this could
componenttext: Can you maybe talk a little bit through the progress making in flow and filtration and kind of it's still early days in many ways, but just talk about where you are in that path and how the quarter as you sort of look forward where do you think this could head in the next 4 quarters.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Beth's progress is good. I mean, no one is we're disappointed about not getting growth in the second quarter than she was. And I think we need to get more traction, and she believes we need to get much traction on the things we're investing to gro
componenttext: I think Beth's progress is good. I mean, no one is we're disappointed about not getting growth in the second quarter than she was. And I think we need to get more traction, and she believes we need to get much traction on the things we're investing to grow. We shouldn't be surprised by what happened in irrigation, and we need to be more and close to the customer. And we need to keep driving on the areas that are working like the shift to industrial water and capture as much of the infrastructure investment is possible. We still believe that there is probably more growth opportunities in the offerings that she leads and the markets that she serves and any other business we have. There's no reason shouldn't be able to perform and grow just like WQS.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what are the biggest ones that jumped out that besides sort of the Chinese water with that we all saw last year?
componenttext: And what are the biggest ones that jumped out that besides sort of the Chinese water with that we all saw last year?

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the Infrastructure globally, there's a return to investments, particularly in reverse osmosis and other water filtration on the municipal and the commercial scale. We have leading positions in advanced technologies for water reuse, methane capture,
componenttext: Well, the Infrastructure globally, there's a return to investments, particularly in reverse osmosis and other water filtration on the municipal and the commercial scale. We have leading positions in advanced technologies for water reuse, methane capture, CO2 capture for Food & Beverage. And we're having, promising early results. We need to flag the zone and get more in those businesses and also just in terms of our membrane technology. I think there's too narrow a focus of where we're applying our technologies, and we need to be planned full about that, but there are opportunities for us to be, if you will, Pentair inside on membranes, in a lot of applications, which where we will be a component supplier to high-value applications.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Randy, if I could just come back at that Valves & Controls answer you gave earlier, I guess coming out of the little bit differently, which is considering how you were thinking about Valves & Controls from kind of day 1 in terms of strategic fit with
componenttext: And Randy, if I could just come back at that Valves & Controls answer you gave earlier, I guess coming out of the little bit differently, which is considering how you were thinking about Valves & Controls from kind of day 1 in terms of strategic fit with the rest of the portfolio and the opportunity, I mean to what extent is -- forgetting price and everything else here, to what extent is the strategic fit of that segment important to how Pentair grows going forward in your mind and the importance to the other segments or from some other perspective that would suggest that it's really still going to be working more to you than to somebody else.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I see a good -- I see a good runway ahead for performance improvement there and what are we good at. We're good at performance improvements. So I think it really turned the quarter and the business. I'm not going to our strategy right here, but it g
componenttext: Well, I see a good -- I see a good runway ahead for performance improvement there and what are we good at. We're good at performance improvements. So I think it really turned the quarter and the business. I'm not going to our strategy right here, but it gives us a great scale, and it has great scale. It's a large player in a large fragmented business. And we speculated before on what needs to happen to the industry, but we're not going to speculate anymore right now.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Tusa from JPMorgan.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the color on the Chinese water business. The tech product segment, the margins were cut there. I know you talked about the mix. Is there any -- how do you look at the price/cost dynamics there and how much deal do you guys buy on an annual basi
componenttext: Thanks for the color on the Chinese water business. The tech product segment, the margins were cut there. I know you talked about the mix. Is there any -- how do you look at the price/cost dynamics there and how much deal do you guys buy on an annual basis?

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: How much deals to we buy?
componenttext: How much deals to we buy?

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's a couple of hundred million dollars, Steve. I think we take a look at the Technical Solutions margins. It's really simply expectation that we would see the MRO on the aftermarket product side which is a very, very high-margin product line,
componenttext: I think there's a couple of hundred million dollars, Steve. I think we take a look at the Technical Solutions margins. It's really simply expectation that we would see the MRO on the aftermarket product side which is a very, very high-margin product line, kind of basically not gravity. And it was going to -- planning to be flat to up and down double digits in Q2, and so we're seeing a margin squeeze between that product fall off and it was an expectation of that that would rally in the second half and taken away that expectation of the second half now in the anticipation that we're not going to see any recovery in the aftermarket side deferred that recovery to 2017. And so that product decline of double digit is really impacting the squeeze in the margins in Technical Solutions.

componenttext: Yes, I hear you. I think what it feels you got a fairly high pass-through backlog that we're still working on from a standpoint of on-time delivery roughly 70% not great by any standard. I mean not horrible in the industry but not great by Pentair standards so we're working at past-due backlog that's helping revenue. When you take a look at the orders Randy mentioned it means that our conversion ratio is going to be higher. So like as we head into '17 even ending the year at lower orders in '16, we think our conversion ratio is going to get back to historical norms, which is around 51% of orders that are booked and shipped that year. That tracked last year at around 43%. So I think we feel like we're starting to get that mix up, as we mentioned, with more aftermarket standards we feel like right now 17 is an up year versus 16 for income size for sure and orders will continue to rally in 17 from this point that we're looking at.

componenttext: Yes. We're starting to see the downstream investment again. The OpEx has been turned off for some period of time. We're starting to see a fair amount of aftermarket consolidation. So our customer spending with the scaled providers, which gives us great excitement as being a large valves supplier in our space that we're going to see a lot more aftermarket consolidation, and that's a big growth opportunity for us. And then we also are back in the game in the Middle East, and we're starting to see order contribution in the Middle East. We've been out of that game for some time.

componenttext: Yes. We are finishing a job in Q2 that was a fixed big job in the thermal and we had some overruns in the labor side on that project. So that job is ending early Q3. And so with that behind us, we're back to more normal project margins and our normal product margins. So it was 1 large job that we worked  through last year and we have the final labor is going through Q2 and early Q3, and that's behind us.

componenttext: Yes. I don't know if it gets worse from here, Nathan, but I don't think we're planning on it getting too much better from here on these projects. I think -- I personally believe that a lot of that reset in pricing was the foreign exchange resets since lot of these about producers outside the United States the euro going down mid-the products more affordable and I think the big EPCs take advantage of that. So I think it stabilizing now and most people are taking out capacity, but I don't think it's going to recover to the levels of it used to be at either.

componenttext: Okay. Then my other question on water quality solutions, you talked about growth investments in the second half. Can you give us some more color on what those growth investments are and maybe what the impact on margins is in the back half of the year and if those are continuing investments or discrete investments.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Before I get into the specific investments, what I meant was that we had such a nice increase in margins. I just don't think people should expect it to be that good, and we gave you some insights into what we expect the margins to be. The investments
componenttext: Yes. Before I get into the specific investments, what I meant was that we had such a nice increase in margins. I just don't think people should expect it to be that good, and we gave you some insights into what we expect the margins to be. The investments are basically 2 types in 2. One is product innovation and the other one is in channel and geography investments and sales coverage. So maybe it's 50 bps a quarter in investment increase. And one is it's a business that as the conversation about China and the conversation we talked earlier about in the pool business, it really is a business that is yielding the innovations. So product innovation pays. And then as I mentioned, we're applying some of the Pool playbook to Water Purification to get more closer to the customers, and those are the geography and channel investments we're making.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen. We've had a fairly sizable frontline for a period of time, and I think as Randy mentioned, disrupted. We have discounted the larger projects from the expectation that those would close this year. But what we did when we reorganized the sales force
componenttext: Listen. We've had a fairly sizable frontline for a period of time, and I think as Randy mentioned, disrupted. We have discounted the larger projects from the expectation that those would close this year. But what we did when we reorganized the sales force is put a lot more energy around the aftermarket side And one of the things we bring to the table to a lot of the larger customers is the ability to service a vast majority of valves. And the weighted for servicing those right now is on an aggregated buy basis from those customers and also working their factories plants to be able to benefit from that. So that's a big piece of it. The second one is there has been some pent-up demand on the downstream side, especially the MRO downstream. And as we always said, we don't think that that would be different forever, and we started to see that start to come in. So we're not declaring victory yet. I think what we're seeing is we believe that Q2 represents the bottom of the orders, and we're starting to see the increase from here. A double-digit increase off of [ph] Q2 is still a modest level of orders versus what we're used to but it's at least a sign that we're going to see that downstream investment start to come back.

componenttext: Yes, the weather can have an impact than that on the timing of the pool season [indiscernible] last year there was a very, very strong Q2, and we're now back to more normal trend on a year-over-year basis in Q3. And as we shared, our aquatic environment systems business has been growing nearly double digits now for 4, 5 years in a row. So we feel good about the visibility to this number and feel very good about the growth rates for Q3.

componenttextpreview: No. I mean we have a few more factories in the works to reduce, so we're just under 100 total factories for Pentair. And we expect to have reduced it by around 5 or 6 by the beginning of the year to the end of the year. So we're modestly addressing it whe
componenttext: No. I mean we have a few more factories in the works to reduce, so we're just under 100 total factories for Pentair. And we expect to have reduced it by around 5 or 6 by the beginning of the year to the end of the year. So we're modestly addressing it where we feel we have excess capacity to the end markets that we're serving, but we're not aggressively reducing the factory footprint at this time.

componenttext: Just to come back to some products some of the mix issues you're talking about in thermal but for a lot of companies call out particularly price cost obviously it's a steel intensive business. I would imagine -- I would've imagined a bit more support from price cost in this quarter, particularly on the Enclosures side, and maybe a bit more headwind in the second half and I guess all the questions or responses around tech products seem to be focusing more on thermal than on Enclosures or ERICO. So just trying to mention out of then I guess Hoffman or maybe ERICO, specifically, how you see mix evolving there, how you see some of the margin readout particularly as price costs.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've done really well in both price cost and ERICO and Enclosures, and we did single out the thermal business, Josh, primarily because that is not steel-related. It's more of the cable versus the labor and the integration cost to bring that project
componenttext: Yes, we've done really well in both price cost and ERICO and Enclosures, and we did single out the thermal business, Josh, primarily because that is not steel-related. It's more of the cable versus the labor and the integration cost to bring that project to bear. So when we take on the projects and we're doing the design, the engineering and the install and that are being the along, we're going to have a compression oh margins where the product side is down. And as we mentioned the aftermarket MRO sometimes goes to distribution or go direct to the site and get installed, and that's the part that's been down double digits. So we're up significant in the project site. We're down in the product side, and we're experiencing an overall mix and that were up the revenue.

componenttext: Yes. We've got a little bit more short-cycle product shipment and also getting capacity backlog so we see that we are expecting to get slightly higher margins. We moved that through the shipments. And we also, as we mentioned, we took in a fair amount of deferred variances from last year, which we spent more than we should have on the labor side. And we had to bleed that off in the first couple of quarters this year, so we had a little tailwind associated with that.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's in refinery. We're seeing more of the petrochem spending come through, which is actively being bid. One thing that seems pretty clear is that now, now that the rapid decline in capital spending has happened, our customers are really sorted out, not
componenttext: That's in refinery. We're seeing more of the petrochem spending come through, which is actively being bid. One thing that seems pretty clear is that now, now that the rapid decline in capital spending has happened, our customers are really sorted out, not only who's working on, still working for them but which projects are going to go with us. And we skewed to little projects. We talk a lot about big projects because those are things that move the needle a lot, but our average project size is well under $1 million. So those are small outage turnarounds, just maintenance-related activities. And so I think we're going to get into more normalized albeit lower level of how they are deployed.

headline: Pentair plc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the structure itself is the right structure I think when you make this level of change where you have project-oriented salespeople trying to call the aftermarket, they're going to find areas where that's the wrong skill set and I think that's wher
componenttext: I think the structure itself is the right structure I think when you make this level of change where you have project-oriented salespeople trying to call the aftermarket, they're going to find areas where that's the wrong skill set and I think that's where we're going to have to continue to migrate the sales force in the right skill set over time and to say we're optimized at the moment I would say is not accurate. And I think we think this structure is right and what we now need to do is get the processes of the support for the structure operating fully, and then we think we can benefit going forward. Hasn't hurt us. Probably here and there but not dramatically.
